attempting match on: %!17%!
No match node contents append: %!17%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p>Story:&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong><br />
The Orange-bellied Parrot Neophema chrysogaster is a small (41-50g), critically endangered, migratory<br />
parrot that breeds in south-western Tasmania and spends the non-breeding period (April-October) in<br />
coastal areas of south-eastern Australia. During winter, Orange-bellied Parrots inhabit low lying coastal<br />
regions of southeast mainland Australia and are rarely found more than one km from the coast. The<br />
number of individuals counted during coordinated winter surveys has declined from 70-90 individuals<br />
in the 1980s (with a peak of 122 in 1983) to fewer than 20 in each year since 2001 and fewer than 10 in<br />
the last 5 years.</p>

<p>This project aimed to assess whether a reduction in Orange-bellied Parrot non-breeding habitat has<br />
occurred since 1983 which may have contributed to the species decline.</p>

<p><strong>Methods</strong><br />
Records from the Orange-bellied Parrot winter sightings database were combined with<br />
contemporaneous data from the Landsat Thematic Mapper, to develop a series of spatio-temporal<br />
models of Orange-bellied Parrot habitat for six time periods between 1983 and 2015. The pixel size of<br />
25 m x 25 m in our habitat data provides a close approximation to the scale of habitat selection by the<br />
Orange-bellied Parrot. The models predict, on a continuous scale, the likelihood that a 25 m x 25 m<br />
pixel will support Orange-bellied Parrot habitat.</p>

<p>Using the Geoscience Australia data-cube and the National Computing Infrastructure, the project team<br />
created 36 independent datasets from the Landsat chrono-sequence for each epoch. From the set of<br />
?cloud-free? images we derived median (and therefore stable) data for Bands 1, 3, 4, 5 and 7 for each of the summer, winter and autumn seasons at every 25 m x 25 m pixel in the study area. Various standard Landsat indices were then derived from the median images. While the winter and autumn image sets were used in the modelling at their ?native? 25 m spatial resolution, the set of summer images was resampled to 250 m to supply landscape context data to each model. These data were supplied as independent variables because landscape configuration is likely to be a component of OBP feeding and roosting site selection (Ehmke 2009).</p>

<p>The project team used these models to explore shifts in Orange-bellied Parrot habitat availability and utilisation through time.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p>Story:&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong><br />
The Orange-bellied Parrot Neophema chrysogaster is a small (41-50g), critically endangered, migratory<br />
parrot that breeds in south-western Tasmania and spends the non-breeding period (April-October) in<br />
coastal areas of south-eastern Australia. During winter, Orange-bellied Parrots inhabit low lying coastal<br />
regions of southeast mainland Australia and are rarely found more than one km from the coast. The<br />
number of individuals counted during coordinated winter surveys has declined from 70-90 individuals<br />
in the 1980s (with a peak of 122 in 1983) to fewer than 20 in each year since 2001 and fewer than 10 in<br />
the last 5 years.</p>

<p>This project aimed to assess whether a reduction in Orange-bellied Parrot non-breeding habitat has<br />
occurred since 1983 which may have contributed to the species decline.</p>

<p><strong>Methods</strong><br />
Records from the Orange-bellied Parrot winter sightings database were combined with<br />
contemporaneous data from the Landsat Thematic Mapper, to develop a series of spatio-temporal<br />
models of Orange-bellied Parrot habitat for six time periods between 1983 and 2015. The pixel size of<br />
25 m x 25 m in our habitat data provides a close approximation to the scale of habitat selection by the<br />
Orange-bellied Parrot. The models predict, on a continuous scale, the likelihood that a 25 m x 25 m<br />
pixel will support Orange-bellied Parrot habitat.</p>

<p>Using the Geoscience Australia data-cube and the National Computing Infrastructure, the project team<br />
created 36 independent datasets from the Landsat chrono-sequence for each epoch. From the set of<br />
?cloud-free? images we derived median (and therefore stable) data for Bands 1, 3, 4, 5 and 7 for each of the summer, winter and autumn seasons at every 25 m x 25 m pixel in the study area. Various standard Landsat indices were then derived from the median images. While the winter and autumn image sets were used in the modelling at their ?native? 25 m spatial resolution, the set of summer images was resampled to 250 m to supply landscape context data to each model. These data were supplied as independent variables because landscape configuration is likely to be a component of OBP feeding and roosting site selection (Ehmke 2009).</p>

<p>The project team used these models to explore shifts in Orange-bellied Parrot habitat availability and utilisation through time.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

<p><strong>Overview</strong><br />
The Orange-bellied Parrot Neophema chrysogaster is a small (41-50g), critically endangered, migratory<br />
parrot that breeds in south-western Tasmania and spends the non-breeding period (April-October) in<br />
coastal areas of south-eastern Australia. During winter, Orange-bellied Parrots inhabit low lying coastal<br />
regions of southeast mainland Australia and are rarely found more than one km from the coast. The<br />
number of individuals counted during coordinated winter surveys has declined from 70-90 individuals<br />
in the 1980s (with a peak of 122 in 1983) to fewer than 20 in each year since 2001 and fewer than 10 in<br />
the last 5 years.</p>

<p>This project aimed to assess whether a reduction in Orange-bellied Parrot non-breeding habitat has<br />
occurred since 1983 which may have contributed to the species decline.</p>

<p><strong>Methods</strong><br />
Records from the Orange-bellied Parrot winter sightings database were combined with<br />
contemporaneous data from the Landsat Thematic Mapper, to develop a series of spatio-temporal<br />
models of Orange-bellied Parrot habitat for six time periods between 1983 and 2015. The pixel size of<br />
25 m x 25 m in our habitat data provides a close approximation to the scale of habitat selection by the<br />
Orange-bellied Parrot. The models predict, on a continuous scale, the likelihood that a 25 m x 25 m<br />
pixel will support Orange-bellied Parrot habitat.</p>

<p>Using the Geoscience Australia data-cube and the National Computing Infrastructure, the project team<br />
created 36 independent datasets from the Landsat chrono-sequence for each epoch. From the set of<br />
?cloud-free? images we derived median (and therefore stable) data for Bands 1, 3, 4, 5 and 7 for each of the summer, winter and autumn seasons at every 25 m x 25 m pixel in the study area. Various standard Landsat indices were then derived from the median images. While the winter and autumn image sets were used in the modelling at their ?native? 25 m spatial resolution, the set of summer images was resampled to 250 m to supply landscape context data to each model. These data were supplied as independent variables because landscape configuration is likely to be a component of OBP feeding and roosting site selection (Ehmke 2009).</p>

<p>The project team used these models to explore shifts in Orange-bellied Parrot habitat availability and utilisation through time.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues><uri><![CDATA[http://eos.ga.gov.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/csw?service=CSW&request=GetCapabilities]]></uri><title>Catalogue Service CSW</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />

The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. ]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</uri><title>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.<br />
It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</uri><title>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.<br />
It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>

attempting match on: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) delivers optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. </value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) delivers optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. </value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

attempting match on: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!67%!
No match node contents append: %!67%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_resource_type_definition/><field_reviewer/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p>? Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Australia License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_security_classification>

	-<uuid><value>7fe74b54-d972-446a-ac2a-bbd68fb77279</value></uuid><vid><value>269</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1490308522</value></created><changed><value>1493007044</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493007044</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>16</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>407af177-566e-4647-a075-36a835a27827</target_uuid><url>/user/16</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-aaae3f4304da10c4351ec918f32b7f81</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues><uri><![CDATA[http://eos.ga.gov.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/csw?service=CSW&request=GetCapabilities]]></uri><title>Catalogue Service CSW</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_contact><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion><value><![CDATA[<p>Data is transferred using rsync from GA project space to the RDSI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_data_ingestion><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>
	-%!40%!

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi><uri>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</uri><title>http://dx.doi.org/10.4225/25/5487CC0D4F40B</title><options/></field_doi><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The ARG product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets for Australia using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.<br />
It is the intention of GA that this suite of products will be available within a more general framework of nested grids. The grid cell sizes of products comprising this suite will be scalable to facilitate easy data comparison between different products. This format will greatly simplify comparison of image datasets acquired by different sensors at varying spatial scales.<br />
The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are effectively consistent over space and time, and will be instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!70%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_hprm_references><value>D2013-175180</value></field_hprm_references><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact>

	-</field_ingestion_contact><field_license>
	-%!6718%!
	-</field_license><field_maintenance><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 V1.0 replaces previous version V0.1 New data is added continuously (at least once week) . Entire archive will be reprocessed when data spec is upgraded to V2.0 (release schedule not yet determined).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_maintenance><field_maintenance_contact>
	-%!66%!
	-</field_maintenance_contact><field_media_contact>
	-%!69%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-22T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-05-22T22:35:22</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!68%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_for_codes>
	-%!6914%!
	-</field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) delivers optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. </value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Reflectance Grid (ARG) is a suite of new generation EO products from GA. These standard data products deliver optical surface reflectance data across the Australian landmass and its coastal fringes. The resulting datasets are effectively sensor agnostic and future versions of products in this suite are intended to be readily comparable between scales.<br />
The first product in this suite is the ARG25, a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on Landsat imagery. A low resolution grid based on MODIS data is under development.<br />
The ARG25 is the first ARG product to be released by GA. It is based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.<br />
Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.<br />
The ARG25 product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.<br />
This product can be viewed as a data cube, with time as the third dimension. The surface reflectance data for each imaged date and time are stacked in chronological order, with Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI sources being interleaved as appropriate to their acquisition time. Interrogation of this data cube allows the time series for individual grid cells, as well as their heritage and data quality, to be extracted and compared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes>
	-%!117%!
	-</field_processes><field_processes>
	-%!118%!
	-</field_processes><field_processes>
	-%!119%!
	-</field_processes><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-06-21T22:35:22</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!67%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</value><end_value>2017-03-23T22:35:22</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type/><field_resource_type_definition/><field_reviewer/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p>? Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Australia License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_security_classification>

<p>Ability to quantify the scale of the daily desertification of Lake Chad over a 10-year period.</p>

<p>97% accuracy achieved without use of confidence layers to constrain results based on terrain or known surface classes.</p>

<p>Improved accuracy over&nbsp;Google &nbsp;Earth &nbsp;Engine &nbsp;Aqua &nbsp;Monitor.</p>

<p>Significant reduction in processing time over standard approaches.</p>

<p>Case 1, Lake Baringo (Kenya):</p>

<ul>
	<li>3.5 GHz Intel processor (4-core), 64GB RAM, Linux computer.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 1-2 minutes for an annual analysis and ~30 minutes for a full time series (11+ years) analysis.</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 2, Central Rangelands (Colombia):</p>

<ul>
	<li>AWS setup has 36 ?virtual CPU? units, 60 GB memory, 300 GB SSD and 2 TB EBS storage.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 5 to 41 seconds for the annual products and ~6 minutes for a full time series (15 year) analysis</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 3, Lake Chad (Northern Cameroon):</p>

<ul dir="ltr">
	<li>3.5 &nbsp;GHz &nbsp;Intel &nbsp;processor &nbsp;(4-??core), &nbsp;64GB &nbsp;RAM, &nbsp;Linux &nbsp;computer &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Computation &nbsp;time &nbsp;of &nbsp;38 &nbsp;seconds &nbsp;for &nbsp;a &nbsp;full &nbsp;time &nbsp;series &nbsp;(10 &nbsp;years) &nbsp;analysis &nbsp;on &nbsp;a &nbsp;1.2 &nbsp;GHz &nbsp;computer &nbsp;&nbsp;with &nbsp;66GB &nbsp;RAM, &nbsp;8 &nbsp;cores. &nbsp;</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_benefits><field_benefit_type>

<p>Ability to quantify the scale of the daily desertification of Lake Chad over a 10-year period.</p>

<p>97% accuracy achieved without use of confidence layers to constrain results based on terrain or known surface classes.</p>

<p>Improved accuracy over&nbsp;Google &nbsp;Earth &nbsp;Engine &nbsp;Aqua &nbsp;Monitor.</p>

<p>Significant reduction in processing time over standard approaches.</p>

<p>Case 1, Lake Baringo (Kenya):</p>

<ul>
	<li>3.5 GHz Intel processor (4-core), 64GB RAM, Linux computer.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 1-2 minutes for an annual analysis and ~30 minutes for a full time series (11+ years) analysis.</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 2, Central Rangelands (Colombia):</p>

<ul>
	<li>AWS setup has 36 ?virtual CPU? units, 60 GB memory, 300 GB SSD and 2 TB EBS storage.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 5 to 41 seconds for the annual products and ~6 minutes for a full time series (15 year) analysis</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 3, Lake Chad (Northern Cameroon):</p>

<ul dir="ltr">
	<li>3.5 &nbsp;GHz &nbsp;Intel &nbsp;processor &nbsp;(4-??core), &nbsp;64GB &nbsp;RAM, &nbsp;Linux &nbsp;computer &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Computation &nbsp;time &nbsp;of &nbsp;38 &nbsp;seconds &nbsp;for &nbsp;a &nbsp;full &nbsp;time &nbsp;series &nbsp;(10 &nbsp;years) &nbsp;analysis &nbsp;on &nbsp;a &nbsp;1.2 &nbsp;GHz &nbsp;computer &nbsp;&nbsp;with &nbsp;66GB &nbsp;RAM, &nbsp;8 &nbsp;cores. &nbsp;</li>
</ul>

attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>The CEOS Systems Engineering Office (SEO) recently completed testing of the Australian Water Observations&nbsp;from Space (WOfS) algorithm (Reference: Mueller,&nbsp;N.,&nbsp;et al,2016) using sample ?version 2? &nbsp;data cubes over Kenya, Colombia and Cameroon.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>The WOfS analysis results were compared with the <a href="http://www.aqua%E2%80%90monitor.appspot.com">Google Earth Engine Aqua Monitor</a>. The Aqua Monitor results, also based on Landsat data, look nearly the same as the WOFS results. However, the WOFS results using a Data Cube have a significant advantage over the Aqua Monitor tool. The Landsat data is ?analysis?ready? and atmospherically corrected, which leads to more accurate results. The user also has access to all of the pixel-?level information for any portion of the time series. Finally, the output shows the existence of water at any time during the analysis period.</p>

<p>The WOfS results were also compared with the Landsat CFmask Water Mask. The more sophisticated 23-step band-based WOfS algorithm is able to detect water in contaminated lakes, whereas the CFmask algorithm does not detect these lakes.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>Pilot achieved 97% overall accuracy with no additional filtering performed using confidence layers to constrain the results based on terrain slope or known surface classes. The SEO only used the primary 23?step band-??based classification for their analyses.</p>

<p>In the Lake Chad case study, all three algorithms tested showed a consistent trend in desertification (decreased surface water area) over the 10 year period. WOfS shows a trend of (minus) -17,656 square meters per day, or a loss of 1.77 hectares of water per day.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

<p>The CEOS Systems Engineering Office (SEO) recently completed testing of the Australian Water Observations&nbsp;from Space (WOfS) algorithm (Reference: Mueller,&nbsp;N.,&nbsp;et al,2016) using sample ?version 2? &nbsp;data cubes over Kenya, Colombia and Cameroon.</p>

<p>The WOfS analysis results were compared with the <a href="http://www.aqua%E2%80%90monitor.appspot.com">Google Earth Engine Aqua Monitor</a>. The Aqua Monitor results, also based on Landsat data, look nearly the same as the WOFS results. However, the WOFS results using a Data Cube have a significant advantage over the Aqua Monitor tool. The Landsat data is ?analysis?ready? and atmospherically corrected, which leads to more accurate results. The user also has access to all of the pixel-?level information for any portion of the time series. Finally, the output shows the existence of water at any time during the analysis period.</p>

<p>The WOfS results were also compared with the Landsat CFmask Water Mask. The more sophisticated 23-step band-based WOfS algorithm is able to detect water in contaminated lakes, whereas the CFmask algorithm does not detect these lakes.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>Pilot achieved 97% overall accuracy with no additional filtering performed using confidence layers to constrain the results based on terrain slope or known surface classes. The SEO only used the primary 23?step band-??based classification for their analyses.</p>

attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area>
No match node contents append: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type/><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!17%!
No match node contents append: %!17%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_societal_benefit_area>
attempting match on: %!20%!
No match node contents append: %!20%!
attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>James Cook University researchers have used the Water Observations from Space (WOfS) data set along with elevation models&nbsp;to determine the least-cost pathways between permanent water sources as a means to map human dispersal and occupation in Australia during the Pleistocene (<a href="http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf">http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf</a>).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Australia is the driest inhabited continent on earth, but humans dispersed rapidly through much of the arid continental interior after their arrival more than 47,000 y ago. The distribution and connectedness of water across the continent, and particularly in its arid core, played a pivotal role in facilitating and focusing early human dispersal throughout the continent. We analyze the distribution and connectedness of modern permanent water across Australia. The modelled least-cost pathways between permanent water sources indicate that the observed rapid occupation of the continental interior was possible along multiple, well-watered routes and likely was driven by the depletion of high-ranked resources in each newly occupied area over time.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>The Water Observations from Space (WOfS) dataset allows an assessment of the spatial distribution and permanency of standing&nbsp;water in the modern Australian landscape. Here we use this information, coupled with the distribution of small natural permanent water bodies (springs, gnammas, native wells, waterholes, and rockholes) compiled from the 1:250,000 topographic sheets (nationalmap.gov.au) to provide a spatially explicit assessment of the opportunities for Pleistocene human occupation of, and dispersal throughout, Australia. A connected network was produced representing the least-cost distance between water bodies and graded according to terrain cost.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>The analysis suggests that permanent water, connected during periodic inundation events, provided?and provides?effective conduits for human movement over thousands of kilometers through much, but not all, of the continental interior. The WOfS dataset only currently covers the Australian continent. However, it is based on satellite imagery with global coverage. The imagery can be used to derive similar products elsewhere, in turn enabling progression beyond the identification of drainage networks and basins as potential dispersal routes to a more nuanced interpretation that considers the permanency of water across a landscape. The same approach therefore can be used to develop and test models that seek to explain the rapid dispersal of modern humans out of Africa via similar periodically interconnected hydro-ecological networks.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>James Cook University researchers have used the Water Observations from Space (WOfS) data set along with elevation models&nbsp;to determine the least-cost pathways between permanent water sources as a means to map human dispersal and occupation in Australia during the Pleistocene (<a href="http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf">http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2016/09/21/1608470113.full.pdf</a>).&nbsp;</p>

<p>Australia is the driest inhabited continent on earth, but humans dispersed rapidly through much of the arid continental interior after their arrival more than 47,000 y ago. The distribution and connectedness of water across the continent, and particularly in its arid core, played a pivotal role in facilitating and focusing early human dispersal throughout the continent. We analyze the distribution and connectedness of modern permanent water across Australia. The modelled least-cost pathways between permanent water sources indicate that the observed rapid occupation of the continental interior was possible along multiple, well-watered routes and likely was driven by the depletion of high-ranked resources in each newly occupied area over time.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>The Water Observations from Space (WOfS) dataset allows an assessment of the spatial distribution and permanency of standing&nbsp;water in the modern Australian landscape. Here we use this information, coupled with the distribution of small natural permanent water bodies (springs, gnammas, native wells, waterholes, and rockholes) compiled from the 1:250,000 topographic sheets (nationalmap.gov.au) to provide a spatially explicit assessment of the opportunities for Pleistocene human occupation of, and dispersal throughout, Australia. A connected network was produced representing the least-cost distance between water bodies and graded according to terrain cost.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong></p>

<p>The analysis suggests that permanent water, connected during periodic inundation events, provided?and provides?effective conduits for human movement over thousands of kilometers through much, but not all, of the continental interior. The WOfS dataset only currently covers the Australian continent. However, it is based on satellite imagery with global coverage. The imagery can be used to derive similar products elsewhere, in turn enabling progression beyond the identification of drainage networks and basins as potential dispersal routes to a more nuanced interpretation that considers the permanency of water across a landscape. The same approach therefore can be used to develop and test models that seek to explain the rapid dispersal of modern humans out of Africa via similar periodically interconnected hydro-ecological networks.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

attempting match on: </field_societal_benefit_area><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To determine how vegetation responds to flow events, specifically to identify correlations between the average NDVI time series values for:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge</li>
	<li>particular vegetation types at Gunbower and the flow at the Torrumbarry gauge.</li>
</ul>

<p>Such correlations could be used to inform vegetation response models, and hence predict outcomes from environmental watering events.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA generated the NDVI values for each 25 meter cell in all the Landsat passes over Gunbower. In-house developed Python scripts were then used to filter out the suitable tiles which were then clipped to the spatial extent of interest.</p>

<p>So that NDVI values could be compared to flow and rainfall data, the NDVI data was processed to generate a time series of average NDVI values. This applied an average NDVI value for the date the image was taken. The data was then able to be analysed for trends in association with the flow and rainfall data to identify correlations between NDVI and flow events.</p>

<p>Analysis included investigating the flow events preceding significant changes in NDVI values to determine any correlations. These were then compared to environmental water requirements flow thresholds for the area.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>b2e6df6e-9a36-421e-9b93-5bc342f3fc5a</value></uuid><vid><value>221</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>c363da33-818b-4428-94e1-24f6aae07974</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Lake Victoria Salinity and Destocking Response</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1490242471</value></created><changed><value>1490242595</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1490242595</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1725f8868fac70ee9d8a69466208ace0</value></_rev><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits/><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>b2e6df6e-9a36-421e-9b93-5bc342f3fc5a</value></uuid><vid><value>221</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>c363da33-818b-4428-94e1-24f6aae07974</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Lake Victoria Salinity and Destocking Response</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1490242471</value></created><changed><value>1490242595</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1490242595</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1725f8868fac70ee9d8a69466208ace0</value></_rev><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits/><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>

attempting match on: %!108%!

attempting match on: %!110%!
No match node contents append: %!110%!
attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type>
No match node contents append: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type>
attempting match on: %!9%!
No match node contents append: %!9%!
attempting match on: </field_issue_type><field_issue_type>
No match node contents append: </field_issue_type><field_issue_type>
attempting match on: %!10%!
No match node contents append: %!10%!
attempting match on: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To assess:</p>

<ul>
	<li>changes to salinity over time and</li>
	<li>environmental response to destocking.</li>
</ul>

<p>For salinity, it included assessing changes in the spatial extent of salinity to the south and east of Lake Victoria from the 1980?s to present as a result of land clearing, increased agricultural activity, and lake regulation. Previous studies of the area had shown an increase.</p>

<p>For destocking, it included determining if removal of cattle has led to changes in vegetation coverage and vegetation communities on Noola and Nulla, properties purchased by MDBA in 2003 and 2008 respectively.</p>

<p>The operational purpose was to also try and indicate impacts of climate change and drought, therefore it was important that the time-slices selected for analysing the Landsat archive could also be used as controls.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA suggested using Hovm?ller plots as an initial change detection exercise for the areas of interest. A Hovm?ller plot depicts changes in data values over time along a single line of latitude/longitude. The line is generally depicted on the x-axis, whilst time is along the y-axis. For the Hovm?ller plots prepared for the pilot, the x-axis represented the length of the transect from its start to finish, whilst the data values represented NDVI.&nbsp;</p>

<p>MDBA provided GA with 500 meter transects, appropriately spaced for similar conditions and vegetation, which GA used to drill through the AGDC to generate Hovm?ller plots of NDVI. In total they prepared Hovm?ller plots for 9 transects (2 for destocking and 7 for salinity).</p>

<p>Change detection maps were also generated from annual NDVI statistics by comparing ?greenest? to ?driest? years. This was to assess the landscape before and after the pilot activity, i.e. salinity and destocking. Time series NDVI graphs for point locations were also analysed so existing vegetation monitoring points and soil surveys could be used to validate AGDC observations.</p>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pilot&nbsp;provided a way forward to assess changes around Lake Victoria and provided some understanding of what is and is not possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The NDVI data supplied by GA had limited documentation which made it difficult to understand how it was prepared.</p>

<p>The data format supplied was unfamiliar to the MDBA so the project team had to seek advice on how best to use the data.</p>

<p>The AGDC did not enable a broad scale indication of the effect of salinity or destocking. It only identified the severe components and picking out areas affected was difficult. Although a trend was detectable, there was no detail on the trend.with some of the pre-processing of the Lake Victoria NDVI tiles including joining and clipping the tiles and analysing the NDVI in different ways.</p>

<p>The ?greenness? from NDVI annual composite statistics was used to filter out annual variations in the plots to improve interpretations, however comparing two years was difficult. In the case of the salinity, there was some indication of bare ground which coincided with existing salinity maps, but there was also the potential for confusing sandy soil with salinity.</p>

<p>GA supplied the numerical outputs (as spreadsheets) for two of the Hovm?ller plots. They were used to select sample areas and time spans from the plot and look at the data in more detail. However, this was difficult to do as the data did not completely correlate with the transect line in the plot. It also created an overestimation of greenness, possibly due to how a transect line cuts across a cell and the value assigned to it.</p>

<p>Although it was initially planned to use Surface Reflectance data (i.e. ARG25) as opposed to NDVI, ARG25 could have provided false results due to the landscape and soil types around Lake Victoria. The limited organic matter in the soils may have also shown up as high reflectance and be mistaken for salinity. Although an attempt was made to download the ARG25 data from the NCI National Research Data Collection, it was quite cumbersome to use therefore not compared.</p>

<p>The Hovm?ller plots were a good tool, especially for communication, as it can show benefits of environmental watering. But the question is how is the tool best delivered to help determine plot transects? The Vegetation Typing Tool, from the ?Vegetation Monitoring in the MDB? project, although potentially useful was a missing part of the puzzle. However it was acknowledged that it was not useful in its current form.</p>

<p>It needs to be noted that after the pilot additional data on vegetation communities became available. This would have assisted with more effectively defining the transects for the Hovm?ller plots.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong></p>

<p>To assess:</p>

<ul>
	<li>changes to salinity over time and</li>
	<li>environmental response to destocking.</li>
</ul>

<p>For salinity, it included assessing changes in the spatial extent of salinity to the south and east of Lake Victoria from the 1980?s to present as a result of land clearing, increased agricultural activity, and lake regulation. Previous studies of the area had shown an increase.</p>

<p>For destocking, it included determining if removal of cattle has led to changes in vegetation coverage and vegetation communities on Noola and Nulla, properties purchased by MDBA in 2003 and 2008 respectively.</p>

<p>The operational purpose was to also try and indicate impacts of climate change and drought, therefore it was important that the time-slices selected for analysing the Landsat archive could also be used as controls.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA suggested using Hovm?ller plots as an initial change detection exercise for the areas of interest. A Hovm?ller plot depicts changes in data values over time along a single line of latitude/longitude. The line is generally depicted on the x-axis, whilst time is along the y-axis. For the Hovm?ller plots prepared for the pilot, the x-axis represented the length of the transect from its start to finish, whilst the data values represented NDVI.&nbsp;</p>

<p>MDBA provided GA with 500 meter transects, appropriately spaced for similar conditions and vegetation, which GA used to drill through the AGDC to generate Hovm?ller plots of NDVI. In total they prepared Hovm?ller plots for 9 transects (2 for destocking and 7 for salinity).</p>

<p>Change detection maps were also generated from annual NDVI statistics by comparing ?greenest? to ?driest? years. This was to assess the landscape before and after the pilot activity, i.e. salinity and destocking. Time series NDVI graphs for point locations were also analysed so existing vegetation monitoring points and soil surveys could be used to validate AGDC observations.</p>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pilot&nbsp;provided a way forward to assess changes around Lake Victoria and provided some understanding of what is and is not possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The NDVI data supplied by GA had limited documentation which made it difficult to understand how it was prepared.</p>

<p>The data format supplied was unfamiliar to the MDBA so the project team had to seek advice on how best to use the data.</p>

<p>The AGDC did not enable a broad scale indication of the effect of salinity or destocking. It only identified the severe components and picking out areas affected was difficult. Although a trend was detectable, there was no detail on the trend.with some of the pre-processing of the Lake Victoria NDVI tiles including joining and clipping the tiles and analysing the NDVI in different ways.</p>

<p>The ?greenness? from NDVI annual composite statistics was used to filter out annual variations in the plots to improve interpretations, however comparing two years was difficult. In the case of the salinity, there was some indication of bare ground which coincided with existing salinity maps, but there was also the potential for confusing sandy soil with salinity.</p>

<p>GA supplied the numerical outputs (as spreadsheets) for two of the Hovm?ller plots. They were used to select sample areas and time spans from the plot and look at the data in more detail. However, this was difficult to do as the data did not completely correlate with the transect line in the plot. It also created an overestimation of greenness, possibly due to how a transect line cuts across a cell and the value assigned to it.</p>

<p>Although it was initially planned to use Surface Reflectance data (i.e. ARG25) as opposed to NDVI, ARG25 could have provided false results due to the landscape and soil types around Lake Victoria. The limited organic matter in the soils may have also shown up as high reflectance and be mistaken for salinity. Although an attempt was made to download the ARG25 data from the NCI National Research Data Collection, it was quite cumbersome to use therefore not compared.</p>

<p>The Hovm?ller plots were a good tool, especially for communication, as it can show benefits of environmental watering. But the question is how is the tool best delivered to help determine plot transects? The Vegetation Typing Tool, from the ?Vegetation Monitoring in the MDB? project, although potentially useful was a missing part of the puzzle. However it was acknowledged that it was not useful in its current form.</p>

<p>It needs to be noted that after the pilot additional data on vegetation communities became available. This would have assisted with more effectively defining the transects for the Hovm?ller plots.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

<p>To assess:</p>

<ul>
	<li>changes to salinity over time and</li>
	<li>environmental response to destocking.</li>
</ul>

<p>For salinity, it included assessing changes in the spatial extent of salinity to the south and east of Lake Victoria from the 1980?s to present as a result of land clearing, increased agricultural activity, and lake regulation. Previous studies of the area had shown an increase.</p>

<p>For destocking, it included determining if removal of cattle has led to changes in vegetation coverage and vegetation communities on Noola and Nulla, properties purchased by MDBA in 2003 and 2008 respectively.</p>

<p>The operational purpose was to also try and indicate impacts of climate change and drought, therefore it was important that the time-slices selected for analysing the Landsat archive could also be used as controls.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong></p>

<p>GA suggested using Hovm?ller plots as an initial change detection exercise for the areas of interest. A Hovm?ller plot depicts changes in data values over time along a single line of latitude/longitude. The line is generally depicted on the x-axis, whilst time is along the y-axis. For the Hovm?ller plots prepared for the pilot, the x-axis represented the length of the transect from its start to finish, whilst the data values represented NDVI.&nbsp;</p>

<p>MDBA provided GA with 500 meter transects, appropriately spaced for similar conditions and vegetation, which GA used to drill through the AGDC to generate Hovm?ller plots of NDVI. In total they prepared Hovm?ller plots for 9 transects (2 for destocking and 7 for salinity).</p>

<p>Change detection maps were also generated from annual NDVI statistics by comparing ?greenest? to ?driest? years. This was to assess the landscape before and after the pilot activity, i.e. salinity and destocking. Time series NDVI graphs for point locations were also analysed so existing vegetation monitoring points and soil surveys could be used to validate AGDC observations.</p>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Pilot&nbsp;provided a way forward to assess changes around Lake Victoria and provided some understanding of what is and is not possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The NDVI data supplied by GA had limited documentation which made it difficult to understand how it was prepared.</p>

<p>The data format supplied was unfamiliar to the MDBA so the project team had to seek advice on how best to use the data.</p>

<p>The AGDC did not enable a broad scale indication of the effect of salinity or destocking. It only identified the severe components and picking out areas affected was difficult. Although a trend was detectable, there was no detail on the trend.with some of the pre-processing of the Lake Victoria NDVI tiles including joining and clipping the tiles and analysing the NDVI in different ways.</p>

<p>The ?greenness? from NDVI annual composite statistics was used to filter out annual variations in the plots to improve interpretations, however comparing two years was difficult. In the case of the salinity, there was some indication of bare ground which coincided with existing salinity maps, but there was also the potential for confusing sandy soil with salinity.</p>

<p>GA supplied the numerical outputs (as spreadsheets) for two of the Hovm?ller plots. They were used to select sample areas and time spans from the plot and look at the data in more detail. However, this was difficult to do as the data did not completely correlate with the transect line in the plot. It also created an overestimation of greenness, possibly due to how a transect line cuts across a cell and the value assigned to it.</p>

<p>Although it was initially planned to use Surface Reflectance data (i.e. ARG25) as opposed to NDVI, ARG25 could have provided false results due to the landscape and soil types around Lake Victoria. The limited organic matter in the soils may have also shown up as high reflectance and be mistaken for salinity. Although an attempt was made to download the ARG25 data from the NCI National Research Data Collection, it was quite cumbersome to use therefore not compared.</p>

<p>The Hovm?ller plots were a good tool, especially for communication, as it can show benefits of environmental watering.
