attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type>
No match node contents append: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type>
attempting match on: %!9%!
No match node contents append: %!9%!
attempting match on: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p>To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although determining depth of water was a ?would like? part of the pilot, it was acknowledged that it was not currently possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDC?s data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDC?s usefulness in supporting the unit?s work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

<p>The pilot confirmed that the AGDC is an important part of the puzzle, especially in providing evidence and eliminating unknowns in understanding the water balance. From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p>To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDC?s data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDC?s usefulness in supporting the unit?s work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
attempting match on: <nid><value>130</value></nid>
Adding node contents to map with id: 131
	-<nid><value>131</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>a03ef9dd-6ffc-4064-94e6-7d87720409c0</value></uuid><vid><value>219</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>user_story</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>c363da33-818b-4428-94e1-24f6aae07974</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Gwydir to Barwon-Darling Environmental Water Release</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1490242258</value></created><changed><value>1490242370</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1490242370</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-48b77280c3f0f0aef18e320c5d47d450</value></_rev><path/><field_additional_changes/><field_benefits/><field_benefit_type/><field_business_activity_change_><value>1</value></field_business_activity_change_><field_contact>
	-%!127%!
	-</field_contact><field_data_collection>
	-%!121%!
	-</field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-09-01</value><end_value>2016-09-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues/><field_issue_type>
	-%!9%!
	-</field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p>To better understand the risks associated with held environmental water flows under current water management arrangements, particularly in the Barwon-Darling. This was also driven by the Northern Basin Advisory Committee (NBAC), especially as it was identified as an emerging risk in the NBR.</p>

<p>It was intended to undertake a water balance through the pilot to deal with water shepherding issues in the north by identifying the:</p>

<ul>
	<li>volume of held environmental water entered into the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>location, area and volume of private storages in the pilot area</li>
	<li>private storages that have filled due to environmental flows</li>
	<li>downstream flow of held environmental water in the Barwon-Darling</li>
	<li>volume and length of time taken for held environmental water to reach Bourke.</li>
</ul>

<p>Although determining depth of water was a ?would like? part of the pilot, it was acknowledged that it was not currently possible with the AGDC.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The original intent of the pilot was for MBDA staff to spend up to a week at GA to learn how to use the AGDC?s data querying interface (i.e. API) and develop the capability to extract the required WOfS tiles from the HPC environment. Once extracted, the tiles would be filtered to remove tiles impacted by cloud, terrain, and high slope to create maps of observed water. These maps would then be used to identify whether private storages have filled as a result of an environmental water release.<br />
Following the first few hours at GA, the approach was revised to improve the likelihood of identifying private storages of interest. The revised two-step approach included:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Generation of quarterly WOfS composites by GA to compare and identify the general fill behaviour of private storages prior and post the water release to identify private storages of interest.</li>
	<li>Interrogation of pixel drill to identify extracted water behaviour over time for the private storages of interest. Pixel drill is a beta online tool developed by GA which gives the water classification results for each individual pixel when selected.</li>
</ol>

<p>Benefits:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated AGDC?s usefulness in supporting the unit?s work, but in association with other information. It demonstrated a non-technical spatial data user can use the AGDC, but with significant support from GIS experienced staff.</p>

<p>The AGDC helped identify private storages where water may have been extracted. The WOfS data was not helpful on its own, but it told a compelling story in association with NDVI and other data. It was also vital in helping endorse anecdotal evidence.</p>

<p>The WOfS data did not provide information on storage volumes, and ultimately was relied on less than the NDVI data. The NDVI quarterly composites were not only useful in observing the likeliness of crops such as cotton crops, but provided sound confirmation of the presence of water. As a broader use, reconciliation of annual composites would be useful for SDL compliance.</p>

<p>The pilot confirmed that the AGDC is an important part of the puzzle, especially in providing evidence and eliminating unknowns in understanding the water balance. From a policy perspective, the pilot provided compelling evidence through its earth observations. It contributed to developing a monitoring process for future work and as an important visual tool in communicating findings to others.</p>

<p>Issues:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prior to the pilot, MDBA staff had limited knowledge of ArcGIS or Python scripting. Plans to spend time at GA to learn to use the AGDC's data querying interface were of limited benefit due to lack of knowledge of the AGDC API and limited training available from GA.</p>

<p>IT security and compatibility issues also prevented MDBA staff from using an MDBA laptop at GA as planned. This was further compounded by NCI access issues experienced at MDBA.</p>

<p>More guidance and organised support earlier in the pilot would have provided a more fruitful experience.</p>

<p>The main issue with the WOfS and NDVI data was the limited explanation of how to use them. The interpretation of the WOfS tile data, especially in relation to the WOfS Pixel Drill, had a significant potential to misinform. It was easy to assume observations impacted by cloud and relief were not wet, thus creating a perceived discrepancy between the WOfS tiles and WOfS Pixel Drill. There was also limited explanation of how GA had processed the quarterly data. However, in most instances the pilot team was able to easily get clarification from GA.</p>

attempting match on: %!121%!
No match node contents append: %!121%!
attempting match on: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-01-01</value><end_value>2016-08-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot 1 indicated concern that the algorithm used to classify water observations in the WOfS data underestimates observed water, especially when compared to the CSIRO algorithm. This creates a significant risk that the flood boundaries generated from the WOfS data fall short from where they should really be. Although some detail of the algorithms used to detect water are included in the WOfS Product Description , additional detail needs to be provided by GA, especially to enable peer review and test the sensitivity of the algorithms.</p>

<p>There is a logical argument for the CSIRO and GA to discuss their respective algorithms so that there is an authoritative one, or at least one more suited for MDBA?s purposes.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_issue_type>
No match node contents append: </field_data_collection><field_date_range><value>2016-01-01</value><end_value>2016-08-01</end_value></field_date_range><field_files/><field_images/><field_issues><value><![CDATA[<p>Pilot 1 indicated concern that the algorithm used to classify water observations in the WOfS data underestimates observed water, especially when compared to the CSIRO algorithm. This creates a significant risk that the flood boundaries generated from the WOfS data fall short from where they should really be. Although some detail of the algorithms used to detect water are included in the WOfS Product Description , additional detail needs to be provided by GA, especially to enable peer review and test the sensitivity of the algorithms.</p>

<p>There is a logical argument for the CSIRO and GA to discuss their respective algorithms so that there is an authoritative one, or at least one more suited for MDBA?s purposes.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_issue_type>
attempting match on: %!10%!
No match node contents append: %!10%!
attempting match on: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne landscape for every 1,000 megalitres/day flows across the floodplain. This additional information is a major input into the Northern Basin Review (NBR), especially regarding specific flow indicators.</p>

<p>This pilot was an MDBA in-house developed satellite imagery-based study of flow inundation based on historical flow events. It was undertaken following the failure of the first version of the CSIRO floodplain inundation model for the Lower Balonne. The CSIRO model was to improve the understanding of the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne for the NBR. However, due to its failure and that delivery of the second version was to be too late for the NBR, the MDBA in-house model (i.e. this pilot) was delivered as an interim version.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The bulk of the effort was filtering the Landsat tiles through:</p>

<ul>
	<li>a hydrograph analysis to remove tiles associated with insignificant flow and antecedent conditions</li>
	<li>an image attribute analysis to ensure that &gt;50% of the tile contains data and &lt;50% of tile is impacted by terrain shadow, high slope, cloud, or cloud shadow.</li>
</ul>

<p>Individual flood zones were developed from analysing gauges with sufficient observed flow data and visually assessing the presence of vegetation in the landscape. The resulting tiles from filtering were then clipped to the extent of the flood zone of interest for further analysis.</p>

<p>In-house scripts were used to prepare the image packages for flood inundation analysis. This included projecting them to a suitable geographic coordinate system and calculating attributes such as area and date taken. They were then married to the flow at the appropriate gauge for that day to create a flow inundation relationship for each flood zone. By looking at the relationship of zones and the attenuation of flows between the various gauges of the zones, it was possible to provide a total inundation for that flow for the whole reach. The workflow was then repeated for vegetation so that total inundation on catchment scale could also be produced.</p>

<p>Plots were generated for the relationship between river flow and total inundation for the flood zone of interest, and also plots were generated for the relationship between flow and vegetation inundation for various vegetation types.</p>

<p>The pilot team used the water classification results for each individual pixel of the WOfS images to generate flood inundation which could then be correlated to river flow rates.</p>

<p>There was considerable effort put into planning and developing the extensive computational analysis suite to produce the inundation results from the WOfS data. This included development of Python scripts to automate processes and to filter WOfS images for further analysis.</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated the importance of having a good understanding of the WOfS data, clear requirements, and appropriate planning. The pilot team?s existing skills in ArcGIS and Python scripting was a major contributor to the methodology, but were also important in developing the appropriate tools to undertake the pilot. This was all undertaken with no dependencies with other areas of the MDBA.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong><br />
The results of the pilot enabled the identification of breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided very good results for the Middle Darling and quite good results for the Culgoa River making it possible to help set Specific Flow Indicators (flow rates designed to lead to particular ecological outcomes) for those regions</p>

<p>The pilot is the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA. However, its true success is that the workflow developed can be fully automated and applied to the whole Basin.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>
No match node contents append: </field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne landscape for every 1,000 megalitres/day flows across the floodplain. This additional information is a major input into the Northern Basin Review (NBR), especially regarding specific flow indicators.</p>

<p>This pilot was an MDBA in-house developed satellite imagery-based study of flow inundation based on historical flow events. It was undertaken following the failure of the first version of the CSIRO floodplain inundation model for the Lower Balonne. The CSIRO model was to improve the understanding of the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne for the NBR. However, due to its failure and that delivery of the second version was to be too late for the NBR, the MDBA in-house model (i.e. this pilot) was delivered as an interim version.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The bulk of the effort was filtering the Landsat tiles through:</p>

<ul>
	<li>a hydrograph analysis to remove tiles associated with insignificant flow and antecedent conditions</li>
	<li>an image attribute analysis to ensure that &gt;50% of the tile contains data and &lt;50% of tile is impacted by terrain shadow, high slope, cloud, or cloud shadow.</li>
</ul>

<p>Individual flood zones were developed from analysing gauges with sufficient observed flow data and visually assessing the presence of vegetation in the landscape. The resulting tiles from filtering were then clipped to the extent of the flood zone of interest for further analysis.</p>

<p>In-house scripts were used to prepare the image packages for flood inundation analysis. This included projecting them to a suitable geographic coordinate system and calculating attributes such as area and date taken. They were then married to the flow at the appropriate gauge for that day to create a flow inundation relationship for each flood zone. By looking at the relationship of zones and the attenuation of flows between the various gauges of the zones, it was possible to provide a total inundation for that flow for the whole reach. The workflow was then repeated for vegetation so that total inundation on catchment scale could also be produced.</p>

<p>Plots were generated for the relationship between river flow and total inundation for the flood zone of interest, and also plots were generated for the relationship between flow and vegetation inundation for various vegetation types.</p>

<p>The pilot team used the water classification results for each individual pixel of the WOfS images to generate flood inundation which could then be correlated to river flow rates.</p>

<p>There was considerable effort put into planning and developing the extensive computational analysis suite to produce the inundation results from the WOfS data. This included development of Python scripts to automate processes and to filter WOfS images for further analysis.</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated the importance of having a good understanding of the WOfS data, clear requirements, and appropriate planning. The pilot team?s existing skills in ArcGIS and Python scripting was a major contributor to the methodology, but were also important in developing the appropriate tools to undertake the pilot. This was all undertaken with no dependencies with other areas of the MDBA.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong><br />
The results of the pilot enabled the identification of breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided very good results for the Middle Darling and quite good results for the Culgoa River making it possible to help set Specific Flow Indicators (flow rates designed to lead to particular ecological outcomes) for those regions</p>

<p>The pilot is the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA. However, its true success is that the workflow developed can be fully automated and applied to the whole Basin.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

<p>There is a logical argument for the CSIRO and GA to discuss their respective algorithms so that there is an authoritative one, or at least one more suited for MDBA?s purposes.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_issues><field_issue_type>
	-%!10%!
	-</field_issue_type><field_primary_change/><field_societal_benefit_area/><field_story><value><![CDATA[<p><strong>Purpose</strong><br />
To better understand the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne landscape for every 1,000 megalitres/day flows across the floodplain. This additional information is a major input into the Northern Basin Review (NBR), especially regarding specific flow indicators.</p>

<p>This pilot was an MDBA in-house developed satellite imagery-based study of flow inundation based on historical flow events. It was undertaken following the failure of the first version of the CSIRO floodplain inundation model for the Lower Balonne. The CSIRO model was to improve the understanding of the behaviour of flows in the Lower Balonne for the NBR. However, due to its failure and that delivery of the second version was to be too late for the NBR, the MDBA in-house model (i.e. this pilot) was delivered as an interim version.</p>

<p><strong>Approach</strong><br />
The bulk of the effort was filtering the Landsat tiles through:</p>

<ul>
	<li>a hydrograph analysis to remove tiles associated with insignificant flow and antecedent conditions</li>
	<li>an image attribute analysis to ensure that &gt;50% of the tile contains data and &lt;50% of tile is impacted by terrain shadow, high slope, cloud, or cloud shadow.</li>
</ul>

<p>Individual flood zones were developed from analysing gauges with sufficient observed flow data and visually assessing the presence of vegetation in the landscape. The resulting tiles from filtering were then clipped to the extent of the flood zone of interest for further analysis.</p>

<p>In-house scripts were used to prepare the image packages for flood inundation analysis. This included projecting them to a suitable geographic coordinate system and calculating attributes such as area and date taken. They were then married to the flow at the appropriate gauge for that day to create a flow inundation relationship for each flood zone. By looking at the relationship of zones and the attenuation of flows between the various gauges of the zones, it was possible to provide a total inundation for that flow for the whole reach. The workflow was then repeated for vegetation so that total inundation on catchment scale could also be produced.</p>

<p>Plots were generated for the relationship between river flow and total inundation for the flood zone of interest, and also plots were generated for the relationship between flow and vegetation inundation for various vegetation types.</p>

<p>The pilot team used the water classification results for each individual pixel of the WOfS images to generate flood inundation which could then be correlated to river flow rates.</p>

<p>There was considerable effort put into planning and developing the extensive computational analysis suite to produce the inundation results from the WOfS data. This included development of Python scripts to automate processes and to filter WOfS images for further analysis.</p>

<p>The pilot demonstrated the importance of having a good understanding of the WOfS data, clear requirements, and appropriate planning. The pilot team?s existing skills in ArcGIS and Python scripting was a major contributor to the methodology, but were also important in developing the appropriate tools to undertake the pilot. This was all undertaken with no dependencies with other areas of the MDBA.</p>

<p><strong>Outcomes</strong><br />
The results of the pilot enabled the identification of breakout of inundation at various flows. It provided very good results for the Middle Darling and quite good results for the Culgoa River making it possible to help set Specific Flow Indicators (flow rates designed to lead to particular ecological outcomes) for those regions</p>

<p>The pilot is the most comprehensive study of historical flood inundation in the Northern Basin undertaken by the MDBA. However, its true success is that the workflow developed can be fully automated and applied to the whole Basin.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format><summary></summary></field_story><field_websites/>

<ul>
	<li>Ocean colour and land reflectance data</li>

	<li>Active fire and burnt area monitoring</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-3 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-3/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>

<p>Band / Center (Spectral Width) [nm]<br />
O1 / 400 (15)<br />
O2 / 412.5 (10)<br />
O3 / 442.5 (10)<br />
O4 / 490 (10)<br />
O5 / 510 (10)<br />
O6 / 560 (10)<br />
O7 / 620 (10)<br />
O8 / 665 (10)<br />
O9 / 673.5 (7.5)<br />

O13 / 761.25 (2.5)<br />
O14 / 764.375 (3.75)<br />
O15 / 767.5 (2.5)<br />
O16 / 778.75 (15)<br />
O17 / 865 (20)<br />
O18 / 885 (10)<br />
O19 / 900 (10)<br />
O20 / 940 (20)<br />
O21 / 1020 (40)</p>

<p>The primary objective of OLCI products is to screen the ocean and land surface to harvest information related to biology. OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate study.</p>

<p>OLCI's field of view allows global coverage to be provided in 2-3 days.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-3 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-3/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>

<p>Band / Center (Spectral Width) [nm]<br />
O1 / 400 (15)<br />
O2 / 412.5 (10)<br />
O3 / 442.5 (10)<br />
O4 / 490 (10)<br />
O5 / 510 (10)<br />
O6 / 560 (10)<br />
O7 / 620 (10)<br />
O8 / 665 (10)<br />
O9 / 673.5 (7.5)<br />
O10 / 681.25 (7.5)<br />
O11 / 708.75 (10)<br />
O12 / 753.75 (7.5)<br />
O13 / 761.25 (2.5)<br />
O14 / 764.375 (3.75)<br />
O15 / 767.5 (2.5)<br />
O16 / 778.75 (15)<br />
O17 / 865 (20)<br />
O18 / 885 (10)<br />
O19 / 900 (10)<br />
O20 / 940 (20)<br />
O21 / 1020 (40)</p>

<p>The primary objective of OLCI products is to screen the ocean and land surface to harvest information related to biology. OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate study.</p>

<p>OLCI's field of view allows global coverage to be provided in 2-3 days.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Examples for applications include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring land cover change for environmental monitoring</li>
	<li>Agricultural applications, such as crop monitoring and management to help food security</li>
	<li>Detailed vegetation and forest monitoring and parameter generation (e.g. leaf area index, chlorophyll concentration, carbon mass estimations)</li>
	<li>Observation of coastal zones (marine environmental monitoring, coastal zone mapping)</li>
	<li>Inland water monitoring</li>
	<li>Glacier monitoring, ice extent mapping, snow cover monitoring</li>
	<li>Flood mapping &amp; management (risk analysis, loss assessment, disaster management during floods)</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>

<ul>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>

attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Examples for applications include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring land cover change for environmental monitoring</li>
	<li>Agricultural applications, such as crop monitoring and management to help food security</li>
	<li>Detailed vegetation and forest monitoring and parameter generation (e.g. leaf area index, chlorophyll concentration, carbon mass estimations)</li>
	<li>Observation of coastal zones (marine environmental monitoring, coastal zone mapping)</li>
	<li>Inland water monitoring</li>
	<li>Glacier monitoring, ice extent mapping, snow cover monitoring</li>
	<li>Flood mapping &amp; management (risk analysis, loss assessment, disaster management during floods)</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-2 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>
	-%!6950%!
	-</field_coverage_content_type><field_custodian>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-21T01:41:04</value><end_value>2017-03-21T01:41:04</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>
	-%!66%!
	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Sentinel-2 mission will offer the following capabilities:</p>

<ul>
	<li>systematic global coverage of land surfaces from 56?S to 84?N, including coastal waters;</li>
	<li>high revisit frequency: every five days at the equator under the same viewing conditions;</li>
	<li>a wide field of view: 290 km.</li>
</ul>

<p>Sentinel-2 MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI) has 13 spectral bands in the visible/near infrared (VNIR) and short wave infrared spectral range (SWIR). In particular:</p>

<p>Sentinel-2 Bands/ Central Wavelength (?m) /Resolution (m)<br />
Band 1 - Coastal aerosol / 0.443 / 60<br />
Band 2 - Blue / 0.490 /10<br />
Band 3 - Green / 0.560 / 10<br />
Band 4 - Red / 0.665 / 10<br />
Band 5 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.705/ 20<br />
Band 6 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.740 / 20<br />
Band 7 - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.783 / 20<br />
Band 8 - NIR / 0.842 / 10<br />
Band 8A - Vegetation Red Edge / 0.865 / 20<br />
Band 9 - Water vapour / 0.945 / 60<br />
Band 10 - SWIR - Cirrus / 1.375 / 60<br />
Band 11 - SWIR / 1.610 / 20<br />
Band 12 - SWIR / 2.190 / 20</p>

<p>The average observation time per orbit is 17 min, while the peak value is 32 min. The combination of the large swath and broad spectral range, coupled with the requirement for global and continuous acquisition with a high revisit frequency, will lead to the generation of about 1.6 TBytes of compressed raw image data each day from the constellation of two satellites.</p>

<p>Sentinel-2's multi-spectral imager undertakes systematic acquisition in a single observation mode. Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-2 MSI will distribute Level-1C product only: Top of atmosphere reflectances in fixed cartographic geometry (combined UTM projection and WGS84 ellipsoid). Level-1C images are a set of tiles of 100 km2, each of which is approximately 500 MB. These products contain applied radiometric and geometric corrections (including orthorectification and spatial registration). More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product-types/level-1c">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-2-msi/product...</a></p>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-1 SAR</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Potential applications are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring sea ice zones and the Arctic environment, and surveillance of marine environment.</li>
	<li>Monitoring land surface motion risks</li>
	<li>Mapping of land surfaces: forest, water and soil</li>
	<li>Mapping in support of humanitarian aid in crisis situations</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-1/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>
	-%!6950%!
	-</field_coverage_content_type><field_custodian>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-21T01:41:04</value><end_value>2017-03-21T01:41:04</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact>

	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>Sentinel-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data products are acquired in Stripmap (SM), Interferometric Wide swath (IW), Extra Wide swath (EW) and Wave (WV) mode and are distributed at three levels of processing:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Level-0: SAR raw data</li>
	<li>Level-1: Single Look Complex (SLC) data comprising complex imagery with amplitude and phase, and Ground Range Detected (GRD) data with multi-looked intensity only;</li>
	<li>Level-2: Ocean (OCN) data for retrieved geophysical parameters of the ocean.</li>
</ul>

<p>More information at: <a href="https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product-types-processing-levels">https://sentinel.esa.int/web/sentinel/user-guides/sentinel-1-sar/product...</a></p>

<p>A single SENTINEL-1 satellite is potentially able to map the global landmasses in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, in a single pass (ascending or descending). The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle at the equator. Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space Statistics 25m 2.1.5</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WO_2.1.5 and WO_STATS_2.1.5 products is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the products provide an indication of the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. The products have also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the products provide an indication of the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. The products have also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>81568</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_STATS_2.1.5 delivers statistics of the WO_2.1.5 data in cumulative "summaries" that combine all water observations from the entire time series into a gridded datasets. Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. Five statistics are calculated and delivered as individual dataset: There are five datasets:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Total number of wet observation for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and wet for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Summary, is the ratio of clear wet observations to clear wet or dry observation, expressed as a percentage.</li>
	<li>Confidence, is a value assigned to each pixel based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. It indicates how well the Summary indicates the presence of water in a pixel.</li>
	<li>Filtered Summary, is produced by combining the Summary and Confidence outputs to mask out those areas where Confidence is less than 1%. Online display of the Water Observations from Space suite of products defaults to the Filtered Summary.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>81568</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_STATS_2.1.5 delivers statistics of the WO_2.1.5 data in cumulative "summaries" that combine all water observations from the entire time series into a gridded datasets. Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. Five statistics are calculated and delivered as individual dataset: There are five datasets:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Total number of wet observation for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and wet for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Summary, is the ratio of clear wet observations to clear wet or dry observation, expressed as a percentage.</li>
	<li>Confidence, is a value assigned to each pixel based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. It indicates how well the Summary indicates the presence of water in a pixel.</li>
	<li>Filtered Summary, is produced by combining the Summary and Confidence outputs to mask out those areas where Confidence is less than 1%. Online display of the Water Observations from Space suite of products defaults to the Filtered Summary.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Water Observations from Space Statistics (WO_STATS_2.1.5) is a set of gridded datasets derived from the Water Observations from Space dataset (WO_2.1.5). WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides five statistical summaries of the WO_2.1.5 dataset:</p>

<ul>
	<li>the number of clear satellite observations from 1987 to present day;</li>
	<li>the number of occasions water was detected;</li>
	<li>the percentage of clear observations on which water was detected;</li>
	<li>the confidence (or probability) that a water observation in this location is correct. This is a percentage, based on a number of factors including the slope of the land and the existence of other corroborative evidence.</li>
	<li>The percentage of clear observations on which water was detected, masked where the confidence is less than 1%.</li>
	<li>WO_STATS_2.1.5 is updated for each update of WO_2.1.5.</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Water Observations from Space Statistics 25m 2.1.5</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purpose of the WO_2.1.5 and WO_STATS_2.1.5 products is to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. This has application in emergency management and risk assessment.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example the products provide an indication of the permanence of surface water in the Australian landscape by showing where water is observed rarely in comparison to where it is often observed. This has application in water management and mapping. The products have also been used for wetland analyses, water connectivity and surface-ground water relationships.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Water Observations from Space product (WO_2.1.5) is a key component of the National Flood Risk Information Portal (NFRIP), developed by Geoscience Australia (GA). The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-</field_custodian><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T23:30:13</value><end_value>2017-03-20T23:30:13</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources>

	-</field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>81568</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_STATS_2.1.5 delivers statistics of the WO_2.1.5 data in cumulative "summaries" that combine all water observations from the entire time series into a gridded datasets. Each WOFL in WO_2.1.5 provides information for each pixel, defining whether an observation was clear and dry, clear and wet or masked due to the presence of clouds, shadows or technical issues with the observation. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides basic statistical summaries of the observation of each pixel through the entire time series from 1987 to present. Five statistics are calculated and delivered as individual dataset: There are five datasets:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Total number of clear observations for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and either wet or dry for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Total number of wet observation for the pixel, is a count per pixel of the number of observations that were clear and wet for the full depth of the time series.</li>
	<li>Summary, is the ratio of clear wet observations to clear wet or dry observation, expressed as a percentage.</li>
	<li>Confidence, is a value assigned to each pixel based on a statistical analysis of factors, including topographic position, elevation and slope, other independent satellite observations of water, topographic maps of water features, and the observation frequency. It indicates how well the Summary indicates the presence of water in a pixel.</li>
	<li>Filtered Summary, is produced by combining the Summary and Confidence outputs to mask out those areas where Confidence is less than 1%. Online display of the Water Observations from Space suite of products defaults to the Filtered Summary.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_contact><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
No match node contents append: </field_contact><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian>
attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>Data is provided as time series stacks of Water Observation Feature Layers (WOFLs), in a 1 to 1 relationship with the input satellite data. Hence, there is one WOFL for each surface reflectance dataset processed for the occurrence of water in the tile location. WOFLs are stacked into time series NetCDF-CF files for each tile location. WOFLs are structured as bitmap products indicating the presence/absence of water and any detected confounding pixel quality issues. The bit flags are non-exclusive, so multiple bits may be set to indicate the presence of multiple factors. The frequency of observation for WOfS varies according to which satellites were operational during which years. The breakdown of the satellite observation availability is as follows:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987 - 1998: Landsat 5</li>
	<li>1999: Landsat 5 and Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2000 - 2003: Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2003 - 2011: Landsat 5 and Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2011 - 2013: Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2013 onward: Landsat 7 and Landsat 8</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_data_description><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T05:35:56</value><end_value>2017-03-20T05:35:56</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact/><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity/><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>WO_25_2.1.5 shows water observed for every Landsat-5, Landsat-7 and Landsat-8 image across Australia (excluding External Territories) for the period of 1987 to 2016. The dataset is updated quarterly and is expected to increase in update frequency in the future so that as a satellite acquires data, it will automatically be analysed for the presence of water and added to the WO_25_2.1.5 product in near real time.<br />
Data is provided as Water Observation Feature Layers (WOFLs), in a 1 to 1 relationship with the input satellite data. Hence there is one WOFL for each NBAR dataset processed for the occurrence of water. The details of the content of each WOFL is below.<br />
In the future, WO_25_2.1.5 will be updated as new data are added. This is potentially possible because the dataset is produced using the Australian Geoscience Data Cube, containing GA's entire Australian Landsat archive in a supercomputing environment at the National Computational Infrastructure at the Australian National University.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact/><field_license>
No match node contents append: </field_custodian><field_data_description><value><![CDATA[<p>Data is provided as time series stacks of Water Observation Feature Layers (WOFLs), in a 1 to 1 relationship with the input satellite data. Hence, there is one WOFL for each surface reflectance dataset processed for the occurrence of water in the tile location. WOFLs are stacked into time series NetCDF-CF files for each tile location. WOFLs are structured as bitmap products indicating the presence/absence of water and any detected confounding pixel quality issues. The bit flags are non-exclusive, so multiple bits may be set to indicate the presence of multiple factors.
