match node contents append: <nid><value>120</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>248b520f-a67d-45c5-a260-dfc3fbc2cfed</value></uuid><vid><value>202</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489986720</value></created><changed><value>1489987746</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489987746</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-8d38b89c3c3c1ad019208023e0742588</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>248b520f-a67d-45c5-a260-dfc3fbc2cfed</value></uuid><vid><value>202</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489986720</value></created><changed><value>1489987746</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489987746</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-8d38b89c3c3c1ad019208023e0742588</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>sr_medoid_albers</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>

No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

No match node contents append: </field_processes><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type>

attempting match on: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!67%!
No match node contents append: %!67%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

	-<uuid><value>248b520f-a67d-45c5-a260-dfc3fbc2cfed</value></uuid><vid><value>202</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489986720</value></created><changed><value>1489987746</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489987746</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-8d38b89c3c3c1ad019208023e0742588</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

	-%!6663%!

	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-06-18T05:12:00</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!67%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</value><end_value>2017-03-20T05:12:00</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>c06d5f0b-9f33-4bbc-9d1f-9e47bb0172b2</value></uuid><vid><value>198</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489982293</value></created><changed><value>1489982393</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489982393</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-c6bbd15a7f3a6deb3c5df9816005ceab</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>

No match node contents append: <uuid><value>c06d5f0b-9f33-4bbc-9d1f-9e47bb0172b2</value></uuid><vid><value>198</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489982293</value></created><changed><value>1489982393</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489982393</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-c6bbd15a7f3a6deb3c5df9816005ceab</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose/><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

matches: [0] = <nid><value>115 [1] = nid [2] = 115
match node contents append: <nid><value>115</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>ad3e09d1-4c20-4aa5-a02e-8afe46cfcca6</value></uuid><vid><value>200</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_GEOMEDIAN_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489975826</value></created><changed><value>1489983773</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489983773</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-a4f891064e7c84cbaf1b1560ebeef729</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>ad3e09d1-4c20-4aa5-a02e-8afe46cfcca6</value></uuid><vid><value>200</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_GEOMEDIAN_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489975826</value></created><changed><value>1489983773</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489983773</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-a4f891064e7c84cbaf1b1560ebeef729</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>103501</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian product provides the median surface reflectance of each calendar year. The geomedian is a synthetic value as opposed to an actual observation, and is the high dimensional median of all reflectance bands of the source dataset for each year.</p>

<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

The geomedian is a synthetic value as opposed to an actual observation, and is the high dimensional median of all reflectance bands of the source dataset for each year.</p>

<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction data.</p>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Statistics products are derived from SR and provide statistical summaries of SR over specified periods (epochs) to highlight extrema, average conditions, or other statistical quantities that give insight into the behaviour of the earth. The geometric median (Geomedian) provides a high dimensional median (the median of a multi-dimensional dataset rather than the basic median) value of earth observations for a specified epoch, and as such gives a representation of the middle of surface reflectance over the time period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Statistics products are derived from SR and provide statistical summaries of SR over specified periods (epochs) to highlight extrema, average conditions, or other statistical quantities that give insight into the behaviour of the earth. The geometric median (Geomedian) provides a high dimensional median (the median of a multi-dimensional dataset rather than the basic median) value of earth observations for a specified epoch, and as such gives a representation of the middle of surface reflectance over the time period.</p>

attempting match on: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!67%!
No match node contents append: %!67%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. ]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_security_classification>
No match node contents append: </field_resource_type><field_resource_type_definition/><field_reviewer/><field_rights_statement><value><![CDATA[<p>? Commonwealth of Australia (Geoscience Australia) 2015. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Australia License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_rights_statement><field_security_classification>
attempting match on: %!6725%!
No match node contents append: %!6725%!
attempting match on: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance Geometric Median 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_software_dependencies>
No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance Geometric Median 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_software_dependencies>
attempting match on: %!116%!
No match node contents append: %!116%!
attempting match on: </field_software_dependencies><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geometric medians of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per calendar year, on individual sensors (ie. only Lndsat 5 TM or Landsat 7 ETM+ or Landsat 8 OLI) to maintain data integrity. An annual geometric median (geomedian) is a high-dimensional median calculated from the reflectance values drawn from a calendar year. The years available are each full calendar year since 1987. The geomedian (Roberts et al 2017) is used in preference to the mean, as the mean can be adversely effected by extrema whereas the median is less sensitive to outliers. The geomedian is used in preference to the basic median, as it preserves the physical relationship between spectral measurements which the basic median does not. The geometric median is used in preference to the medoid (Flood 2013) as the medoid must choose from available measurements and hence may create a noisy composite, while the geomedian creates a synthetic representation of an epoch while reducing noise and permitting further analysis that is consistent with mathematical and statistical theory. Where the provenance of each pixel in a composite is required the medoid is the preferred method and the geomedian should not be used. The input data used to calculate the geomedian are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band) using the Pixel Quality Assessment (PQA) product. To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites/sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>2011 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2012 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2013 : Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2014 onward : Landsat 8</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>
No match node contents append: </field_software_dependencies><field_subject_matter_experts/><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geometric medians of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per calendar year, on individual sensors (ie. only Lndsat 5 TM or Landsat 7 ETM+ or Landsat 8 OLI) to maintain data integrity. An annual geometric median (geomedian) is a high-dimensional median calculated from the reflectance values drawn from a calendar year. The years available are each full calendar year since 1987. The geomedian (Roberts et al 2017) is used in preference to the mean, as the mean can be adversely effected by extrema whereas the median is less sensitive to outliers. The geomedian is used in preference to the basic median, as it preserves the physical relationship between spectral measurements which the basic median does not. The geometric median is used in preference to the medoid (Flood 2013) as the medoid must choose from available measurements and hence may create a noisy composite, while the geomedian creates a synthetic representation of an epoch while reducing noise and permitting further analysis that is consistent with mathematical and statistical theory. Where the provenance of each pixel in a composite is required the medoid is the preferred method and the geomedian should not be used. The input data used to calculate the geomedian are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band) using the Pixel Quality Assessment (PQA) product. To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites/sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5</li>
	<li>2011 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2012 : Landsat 7</li>
	<li>2013 : Landsat 7 and Landsat 8 (as separate geomedian products)</li>
	<li>2014 onward : Landsat 8</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>

	-<uuid><value>ad3e09d1-4c20-4aa5-a02e-8afe46cfcca6</value></uuid><vid><value>200</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_GEOMEDIAN_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489975826</value></created><changed><value>1489983773</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489983773</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-a4f891064e7c84cbaf1b1560ebeef729</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
