	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>103501</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian product provides the median surface reflectance of each calendar year. The geomedian is a synthetic value as opposed to an actual observation, and is the high dimensional median of all reflectance bands of the source dataset for each year.</p>

<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Statistics products are derived from SR and provide statistical summaries of SR over specified periods (epochs) to highlight extrema, average conditions, or other statistical quantities that give insight into the behaviour of the earth. The geometric median (Geomedian) provides a high dimensional median (the median of a multi-dimensional dataset rather than the basic median) value of earth observations for a specified epoch, and as such gives a representation of the middle of surface reflectance over the time period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

	-%!6662%!
	-</field_product_type><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-06-18T02:10:26</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
	-%!67%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</value><end_value>2017-03-20T02:10:26</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>

<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>

<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types. Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>

<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>

<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>

<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>

<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
	-%!6675%!

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>The product is derived from surface reflectance data described in the ARG25 product description. This product includes quality assurance information for each pixel.</p>

<p>The products are produced through the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC). The Data Cube allows the workflows for the product, once developed, to be run over large areas at marginal cost, offering major efficiencies and cost savings over previous approaches and enabling more timely and effective monitoring and management.</p>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The ?seasonal? statistics of surface reflectance measurements are calculated per season (three months)<br />
- Dec/Jan/Feb - Season 1<br />
- Mar/Apr/May - Season 2<br />
- Jun/July/August - Season 3<br />
- September/October/November - Season 4</p>

<p>Each epoch is summarised using the geo-median.</p>

<p>Statistics are drawn from the reflectance values for each epoch. The epochs available are the most recent 8 seasons and each full calendar year since 1987</p>

<p>The input data used to calculate the geo-median are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band). Sea is not filtered. Water is not filtered.</p>

match node contents append: <nid><value>113</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>b3331362-89b5-4d14-ada5-6e8829dcea26</value></uuid><vid><value>193</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489971879</value></created><changed><value>1489972573</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489972573</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-364a0c6edbd1ae2ba6b3550131560193</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>b3331362-89b5-4d14-ada5-6e8829dcea26</value></uuid><vid><value>193</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489971879</value></created><changed><value>1489972573</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489972573</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-364a0c6edbd1ae2ba6b3550131560193</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>

	-<uuid><value>b3331362-89b5-4d14-ada5-6e8829dcea26</value></uuid><vid><value>193</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_COUNT_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489971879</value></created><changed><value>1489972573</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489972573</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-364a0c6edbd1ae2ba6b3550131560193</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>

This information can also be used to normalise observation counts of particular phenomena. For example what percentage of time did a pixel meet a particular criteria during a particular year.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics. The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor). The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>

<p>The PQ25-STATS product is a summary of all of the individual PQ_25 layers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Pixel Quality (PQ) product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an un-obscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels from which don?t meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>The PQ-STATS shows the breakdown of how many times a pixel contains a clear observation of the surface (land or sea).</p>

<p>PQ-STATS is available as a per year summary and as a 'whole of archive' summary (1987 to present).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Pixel Quality (PQ) product is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an un-obscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels from which don?t meet their quality criteria from further analysis. The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels from analysis is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>The PQ-STATS shows the breakdown of how many times a pixel contains a clear observation of the surface (land or sea).</p>

<p>PQ-STATS is available as a per year summary and as a 'whole of archive' summary (1987 to present).</p>

No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title><value>ndvi_stats_10th_percentile_albers</value></field_developer_title><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for NDVI.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated from observations made by the following sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>2011-2012 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2013 onward : Landsat 8 OLI</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for NDVI.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated from observations made by the following sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>2011-2012 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2013 onward : Landsat 8 OLI</li>
</ul>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of NDVI. The NDVI statistics are calculated from the observations in the NDVI product (NDVI_25_2.0.0) that are not affected by cloud, cloud shadow or sensor saturation (as captured by the PQ_25_2.0.0 product)</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of NDVI and low vegetation cover i.e. 10th percentile of NDVI that occurred within the compositing period. It is worth noting that in areas that are subject to inundation (clay pans, salt lakes, rivers, lakes, floodplains, wetlands) the percentile values of NDVI may be affected by open water. In these settings NDVI values may not be representative of 'vegetation cover'.</p>

<p>Seasons are defined as:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Season 1: December, January, February</li>
	<li>Season 2: March, April, May,</li>
	<li>Season 3: June, July, August</li>
	<li>Season 4: September, October, November</li>
</ul>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for NDVI.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated from observations made by the following sensors for the following periods of time:</p>

<ul>
	<li>1987-1998 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>1999 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2000-2002 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2003 : Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2004-2010 : Landsat 5 TM</li>
	<li>2011-2012 : Landsat 7 ETM+</li>
	<li>2013 onward : Landsat 8 OLI</li>
</ul>

matches: [0] = <nid><value>109 [1] = nid [2] = 109
match node contents append: <nid><value>109</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>58e80888-5de3-43ad-82ff-ebe72542093e</value></uuid><vid><value>187</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489963097</value></created><changed><value>1489963256</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489963256</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1212a6aba34052212fd7605ccb5d97e0</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>58e80888-5de3-43ad-82ff-ebe72542093e</value></uuid><vid><value>187</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489963097</value></created><changed><value>1489963256</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489963256</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1212a6aba34052212fd7605ccb5d97e0</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
attempting match on: <nid><value>108</value></nid>
Adding node contents to map with id: 109
	-<nid><value>109</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>58e80888-5de3-43ad-82ff-ebe72542093e</value></uuid><vid><value>187</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489963097</value></created><changed><value>1489963256</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489963256</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1212a6aba34052212fd7605ccb5d97e0</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

NDVI provides the ability to assess the relative extent of living green vegetation across the Australian continent at any point in time since 1987 till now. NDVI can potentially provide insight into the health and/or growth of vegetation whilst allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-</field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>fk4</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>NDVI is an indicator used to assess the degree of live green vegetation at a given location.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>

<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

NDVI provides the ability to assess the relative extent of living green vegetation across the Australian continent at any point in time since 1987 till now. NDVI can potentially provide insight into the health and/or growth of vegetation whilst allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

However the frequency with with which a particular location is observed depends on a range of factors including satellite overpass, cloud and cloud shadows. This product is a rolling composite of data that is updated on a monthly basis and shows the most up-to-date observation for every pixel. The product consists of two components, the surface reflectance data, and the date of observation.</p>

This product is a rolling composite of data that is updated on a monthly basis and shows the most up-to-date observation for every pixel. The product consists of two components, the surface reflectance data, and the date of observation.</p>

<p>A value of 2832 equates to a surface brightness temperature of 282.2 Kelvin or 10 degrees Celsius</p>

<p>The methodology used calculate surface brightness temperature is described in the following reference:<br />
F. Li, D. L. B. Jupp, M. Thankappan, L-W. Wang, J. Sixsmith, A. Lewis and A. Held (2015) 'Land surface brightness temperature retrieved from Landsat data' MODSIM2015, 21st International Congress on Modelling and Simulation. Modelling and Simulation Society of Australia and New Zealand, December 2015, pp. 490?496. ISBN: 978-0-9872143-5-5.</p>

<p>A value of 2832 equates to a surface brightness temperature of 282.2 Kelvin or 10 degrees Celsius</p>

<p>The methodology used calculate surface brightness temperature is described in the following reference:<br />
F. Li, D. L. B. Jupp, M. Thankappan, L-W. Wang, J. Sixsmith, A. Lewis and A. Held (2015) 'Land surface brightness temperature retrieved from Landsat data' MODSIM2015, 21st International Congress on Modelling and Simulation. attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The collection represents a multi-decadal record of surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) as observed by the Landsat series of satellites (5, 7 and 8).</p>

<p>The ground-sampling-distance of the Landsat thermal sensors is 120 metres (Landsat 5 TM), 60 metres (Landsat 7 ETM+) and 100 metres (Landsat 8 TIRS). All sensors are resampled to 25 metres to enable analysis of thermal data in the context of the optical wavelengths.</p>

<p>Whilst the data is resampled to 25 metres, the variable/coarser spatial resolution of the thermal sensors means that caution should be used when measuring features that are at or below 200 metres in scale (~2 ground sample distance units wide).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The collection represents a multi-decadal record of surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) as observed by the Landsat series of satellites (5, 7 and 8).</p>

<p>The ground-sampling-distance of the Landsat thermal sensors is 120 metres (Landsat 5 TM), 60 metres (Landsat 7 ETM+) and 100 metres (Landsat 8 TIRS). All sensors are resampled to 25 metres to enable analysis of thermal data in the context of the optical wavelengths.</p>

<p>Whilst the data is resampled to 25 metres, the variable/coarser spatial resolution of the thermal sensors means that caution should be used when measuring features that are at or below 200 metres in scale (~2 ground sample distance units wide).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

attempting match on: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface temperature (Ts) is a key boundary condition in many remote sensing-based land surface modeling schemes including calculating evapotranspiration, water balance modelling and vegetation condition assessment. Surface brightness temperature is a measure of the temperature of the Earth's surface that has not been corrected for emissivity. The LST_25 product is a 25 metre resolution surface brightness temperature measurement calculated from the Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+ and Landsat 8 TIRS sensors. The surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) is calculated using MODTRAN software and atmospheric profile data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). Per pixel cloud/cloud shadow screening (PQ_25) can be used to screen cloud affected observation from the LST_25 meter product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>

	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The collection represents a multi-decadal record of surface brightness temperature (Kelvin) as observed by the Landsat series of satellites (5, 7 and 8).</p>

<p>The ground-sampling-distance of the Landsat thermal sensors is 120 metres (Landsat 5 TM), 60 metres (Landsat 7 ETM+) and 100 metres (Landsat 8 TIRS). All sensors are resampled to 25 metres to enable analysis of thermal data in the context of the optical wavelengths.</p>

<p>Whilst the data is resampled to 25 metres, the variable/coarser spatial resolution of the thermal sensors means that caution should be used when measuring features that are at or below 200 metres in scale (~2 ground sample distance units wide).</p>

matches: [0] = <nid><value>100 [1] = nid [2] = 100
match node contents append: <nid><value>100</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>64e5bd0c-a5db-4be8-8083-b24eb274f403</value></uuid><vid><value>174</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489714813</value></created><changed><value>1489715182</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489715182</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-d7f10caa3cb01acbbc5d2d26cda29f05</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>

<p>Through attribution of the LOT and HOT values modelled for each cell, the extents model can be used to derive an elevation profile of the observed intertidal zone extent on a cell by cell basis. The method employed can be tailored based on user requirements. For example, by dividing the observed tidal range for a cell (HOT-LOT) into 10% interval values, contours can be assigned to the section of the Intertidal Extents Model contained in that cell. These can then be used as a standalone elevation data source, or interpolated to create a continuous intertidal digital elevation model for the cell.</p>

<p>The ability to create an elevation model relative to MSL enables the data to be integrated as a complimentary data source, linking shallow water bathymetry and terrestrial elevation models.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GA?s historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>

<p>The modelling process to derive the product utilises a continental scale tidal model developed by Oregon State University (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>), applied to the 221 AGDC cells that cover the Australian coastline (Figure 1).</p>

<p>Each Landsat tile in these coastal cells is attributed with a tidal offset, relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL), corresponding to the time of observation acquisition. Tidal offsets are modelled at a single constant location for each 1 degree by 1 degree cell, determined manually and based on the complexity of the coastline contained with the cell.</p>

<p>The time-series of observations for each AGDC cell is then sorted based on the modelled tidal offset, and split into subsets representing 10% percentile intervals of the observed tidal range (OTR) for that cell.</p>

<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>

<p>Each tile observation is masked for pixel quality based on the AGDC PQA layer to exclude pixels flagged for cloud, band saturation and contiguity. The Normalised Difference Water Index (NDWI) (McFeeters, 1996) is calculated for each tile, and a pixel based median NDWI composite derived for each 10% percentile interval of the cell?s OTR.</p>

<p>The ten NDWI composites derived for each cell are used to estimate the extent of exposed substratum at each 10% interval of the OTR, and combined to create the Relative Extents Model.</p>

<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<p>1. Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</p>

<p>2. Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</p>

<p>3. Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian/><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact/><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity/><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT) ? The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT) ? The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at each 10% percentile of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Always water<br />
1 ? Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2 ? Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3 ? Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4 ? Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5 ? Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6 ? Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7 ? Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8 ? Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999 ? No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the 10% intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767 ? No Data</p>

<p>All other values ? The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each 10% percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact/><field_license/><field_maintenance/><field_maintenance_contact/><field_media_contact/><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact/><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity/><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product is a national scale gridded dataset characterising the spatial extents of the exposed intertidal zone, at intervals of the observed tidal range. The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact/><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance/><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>64e5bd0c-a5db-4be8-8083-b24eb274f403</value></uuid><vid><value>174</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489714813</value></created><changed><value>1489715182</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489715182</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-d7f10caa3cb01acbbc5d2d26cda29f05</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>

<p>Through attribution of the LOT and HOT values modelled for each cell, the extents model can be used to derive an elevation profile of the observed intertidal zone extent on a cell by cell basis. The method employed can be tailored based on user requirements. For example, by dividing the observed tidal range for a cell (HOT-LOT) into 10% interval values, contours can be assigned to the section of the Intertidal Extents Model contained in that cell. These can then be used as a standalone elevation data source, or interpolated to create a continuous intertidal digital elevation model for the cell.</p>

<p>The ability to create an elevation model relative to MSL enables the data to be integrated as a complimentary data source, linking shallow water bathymetry and terrestrial elevation models.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GA?s historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>

<p>The modelling process to derive the product utilises a continental scale tidal model developed by Oregon State University (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>), applied to the 221 AGDC cells that cover the Australian coastline (Figure 1).</p>

<p>Each Landsat tile in these coastal cells is attributed with a tidal offset, relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL), corresponding to the time of observation acquisition. Tidal offsets are modelled at a single constant location for each 1 degree by 1 degree cell, determined manually and based on the complexity of the coastline contained with the cell.</p>

<p>The time-series of observations for each AGDC cell is then sorted based on the modelled tidal offset, and split into subsets representing 10% percentile intervals of the observed tidal range (OTR) for that cell.</p>

<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>

<p>Each tile observation is masked for pixel quality based on the AGDC PQA layer to exclude pixels flagged for cloud, band saturation and contiguity. The Normalised Difference Water Index (NDWI) (McFeeters, 1996) is calculated for each tile, and a pixel based median NDWI composite derived for each 10% percentile interval of the cell?s OTR.</p>

<p>The ten NDWI composites derived for each cell are used to estimate the extent of exposed substratum at each 10% interval of the OTR, and combined to create the Relative Extents Model.</p>

<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<p>1. Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</p>

<p>2. Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</p>

<p>3. Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian/><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact/><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity/><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT) ? The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT) ? The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at each 10% percentile of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Always water<br />
1 ? Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2 ? Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3 ? Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4 ? Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5 ? Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6 ? Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7 ? Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8 ? Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999 ? No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the 10% intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767 ? No Data</p>

<p>All other values ? The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each 10% percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact/><field_license/><field_maintenance/><field_maintenance_contact/><field_media_contact/><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact/><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity/><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product is a national scale gridded dataset characterising the spatial extents of the exposed intertidal zone, at intervals of the observed tidal range. The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact/><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance/><field_resource_type>

ITEM provides the extent including the relative height and depth of the intertidal zone of Australia's coastline (excluding off-shore Territories). This information was collated using observations in the Landsat archive since 1987. ITEM can be a valuable complimentary dataset to both onshore LiDAR survey data and coarser offshore bathymetry data, enabling a more realistic representation of the land and ocean interface.</p>
