	-<uuid><value>64e5bd0c-a5db-4be8-8083-b24eb274f403</value></uuid><vid><value>174</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489714813</value></created><changed><value>1489715182</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489715182</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-d7f10caa3cb01acbbc5d2d26cda29f05</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>

<p>Through attribution of the LOT and HOT values modelled for each cell, the extents model can be used to derive an elevation profile of the observed intertidal zone extent on a cell by cell basis. The method employed can be tailored based on user requirements. For example, by dividing the observed tidal range for a cell (HOT-LOT) into 10% interval values, contours can be assigned to the section of the Intertidal Extents Model contained in that cell. These can then be used as a standalone elevation data source, or interpolated to create a continuous intertidal digital elevation model for the cell.</p>

<p>The ability to create an elevation model relative to MSL enables the data to be integrated as a complimentary data source, linking shallow water bathymetry and terrestrial elevation models.</p>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>HLTC_25 is a mosaic produced to allow visualisation of the shallow water and inter-tidal coastal regions as observed at low tide or at high tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the synthetic median surface reflectance values based on an ensemble of tiles observed at the lowest tidal epochs for a specified date range, estimated for each cell in the AGDC archive. The product also includes the count of clear observations per pixel, and the tidal offset range utilised for each cell.</p>

<p>The product will utilise tidal offset values relative to MSL, calculated for each coastal tile observation at time of acquisition, using the Oregon State Tidal Prediction (OTPS) software TPX08 Atlas model (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>).</p>

<p>Observations per coastal cell will then be sorted by tidal offset to obtain tiles corresponding to the lowest 10% of tides observed in the archive. A band based median for each Landsat band will then be calculated from the lowest 10% subset of tiles for each cell.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artefacts.</p>

<p>The product will be calculated for the epoch 1995-2015.</p>

<p>Observations will be filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the synthetic median surface reflectance values based on an ensemble of tiles observed at the lowest tidal epochs for a specified date range, estimated for each cell in the AGDC archive. The product also includes the count of clear observations per pixel, and the tidal offset range utilised for each cell.</p>

<p>The product will utilise tidal offset values relative to MSL, calculated for each coastal tile observation at time of acquisition, using the Oregon State Tidal Prediction (OTPS) software TPX08 Atlas model (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>).</p>

<p>Observations per coastal cell will then be sorted by tidal offset to obtain tiles corresponding to the lowest 10% of tides observed in the archive. A band based median for each Landsat band will then be calculated from the lowest 10% subset of tiles for each cell.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artefacts.</p>

<p>The product will be calculated for the epoch 1995-2015.</p>

<p>Observations will be filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>HLTC_25 is a mosaic produced to allow visualisation of the shallow water and inter-tidal coastal regions as observed at low tide or at high tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the synthetic median surface reflectance values based on an ensemble of tiles observed at the lowest tidal epochs for a specified date range, estimated for each cell in the AGDC archive. The product also includes the count of clear observations per pixel, and the tidal offset range utilised for each cell.</p>

<p>The product will utilise tidal offset values relative to MSL, calculated for each coastal tile observation at time of acquisition, using the Oregon State Tidal Prediction (OTPS) software TPX08 Atlas model (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>).</p>

<p>Observations per coastal cell will then be sorted by tidal offset to obtain tiles corresponding to the lowest 10% of tides observed in the archive. A band based median for each Landsat band will then be calculated from the lowest 10% subset of tiles for each cell.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artefacts.</p>

<p>The product will be calculated for the epoch 1995-2015.</p>

<p>Observations will be filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-17T00:59:20</value><end_value>2017-03-17T00:59:20</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
	-%!64%!
	-</field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-15T00:59:20</value><end_value>2017-06-15T00:59:20</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>

	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The product is composed of the surface reflectance and fractional cover pixels corresponding to the 90th percentile bare soil value in the fractional cover. The product also includes the sensor, observation date and the count of values used to calculate the 90th percentile bare.</p>

<p>Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 8 OLI data will be used for this product, as inclusion of Landsat 7 leaves a large number of data artifacts. Observations are filtered to remove poor quality observations including cloud, cloud shadow, band saturation (of any band), and water.</p>

<p>The product is calculated for the epoch 2000 ? 2015.</p>

	-<uuid><value>8647b469-3fe1-465b-9dbb-f216c6fcd158</value></uuid><vid><value>159</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>external_product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>e8e2a282-c7f3-4b2d-b28f-9e11dae94c9e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>MOD13Q1 Enhanced Vegetation Index data</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489547953</value></created><changed><value>1489547967</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489547967</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-4dea3f3e2f291c60bb3054045e32f4d5</value></_rev><path/>
matches: [0] = <nid><value>89 [1] = nid [2] = 89
match node contents append: <nid><value>89</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>f0f8893f-d31d-4e0c-809a-76e3d432f5b0</value></uuid><vid><value>167</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_250_2.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489546860</value></created><changed><value>1489709349</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489709349</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-8d025ebab2f6c118bdb6d77387a0668b</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The <em>in situ</em> data shown in Figure 4 were compared with the DLCDv2 class recorded during the same year as the <em>in situ</em> data were collected . Cells highlighted in green in the table above represent a match between the in situ data and the DLCDv2 class. Cells highlighted in yellow represent land covers were the DLCDv2 class was similar (but not the same) as the <em>in situ</em> data. For example irrigated cropping is ?similar? to rainfed cropping. Cells highlighted in red were a mismatch between the <em>in situ</em> data and the DLCDv2 class, for example irrigated cropping is a ?mismatch? for ?tussock grasses ? open?. For 22,645 in situ data points recorded, 31% were a match with the DLCDv2 class, 53% were similar and 17% were a mismatch. This fuzzy approach to accuracy assessment was used to address the challenges of assessing a land cover classification with the best available <em>in situ</em> data, as distinct from <em>in situ</em> data that was collected with the express purpose of assessing the accuracy of an EO land cover classification (Foody 1996). Classes for which no <em>in situ</em> data were available (sugar cane, extraction sites, built-up surface) are not included in the accuracy assessment.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 classification is discriminating the managed land cover classes (in total) from the unmanaged land cover classes with a high degree of accuracy, however there is confusion between the managed classes. For example many of the areas labelled as rainfed cropping in the <em>in situ</em> data are captured as irrigated cropping in the DLCDv2 classification. Based on the in situ data the DLCDv2 the extent of grasses is being undersestimated (low producers accuracy indicating errors of omission (Table 2) and the extent of shrubs is being overestimated (low users accuracy indicating errors of commision). The producers and users accuracy for trees are both &gt;60% indicating a reasonable accuracy for tree cover. However the accuracy for specific tree cover classes (closed versus open) is lower, therefore caution should be exercised in assessing the extent of a specific canopy cover class.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Nadir- looking observations: Earth observing instruments on satellites typically record the dominant cover type rather than the tallest cover type, as a consequence of their nadir-looking configuration. The tallest stratum is used in the ISO classification and the vegetation classification schemes used to capture the <em>in-situ</em> data. As a result, changes in the dominant cover type (for example grasses in savannah ecosystems) may have a larger influence on the EVI signal than changes in taller strata (such as trees in a savannah ecosystem). This means that the DLCDv2 is likely to represent the ?Dominant cover type per epoch? rather than the ?Tallest cover type per epoch?.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Land cover classes that are poorly characterised by EVI: Land cover classes that are difficult to characterise using EVI time series include mines, urban areas, irrigated and rainfed sugar cane. These classes are included in the DLCDv2 for the purposes of providing a complete suite of land cover classes, however variation in the extent of these classes is not well captured using EVI and a single spatial extent is applied to all epochs for these classes. As a consequence users who wish to track the change in extent of these classes should refer to alternate data sources. EVI does not discriminate well between inland waters and salt lakes. For detailed information about the spatial extent of surface water please refer to Water Observations from Space at: <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs">http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs</a>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Persistent green pastures: During periods of higher rainfall the pastures-rainfed class can display similar EVI characteristics to trees-open (persistent high EVI). These classes are discriminated using a 500-metre resolution green reflectance product. This means that changes at the interface between rainfed pastures and open forests may not be detected, and that some afforestion activities may not be detected.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Spatial scale limitations: The 250-metre spatial resolution of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. The two-year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short-lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two- year period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Time scale limitations: Whilst the EVI product is available from 2000 onwards, the first map of the DLCDv2 series starts at January 2002. The land cover results for period January 2000 through to December 2001 are impacted by a lack of pre-existing 250-metre scale information about the land cover in the year 2000. As a consequence they are not included in the DLCDv2.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Terrain shadow: Areas that are affected by terrain shadow at the time of image acquisition will show anomolous results in some instances. Areas with deep shadows in winter may occaisonally be misclassified as alpine grasses and sedges. This is a known artefact and will appear scattered along areas corresponding to valley bottoms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Severe bushfires: Severe bushfires such as those that occurred on Black Saturday 2009 and the Canberra fire storm in 2003 create unusual EVI responses within a 2-year interval. As a result the land cover class in the map interval following the major fire may be inaccurate. Care should be used when interpreting the land cover maps in areas that have been subject to severe fire.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purposes of the DLCDv2.1 product are to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding and reporting on land cover change, and to assist policy makers to assess how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the ABS Land Accounts.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 as a model input parameter. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>f0f8893f-d31d-4e0c-809a-76e3d432f5b0</value></uuid><vid><value>167</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_250_2.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489546860</value></created><changed><value>1489709349</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489709349</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-8d025ebab2f6c118bdb6d77387a0668b</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The <em>in situ</em> data shown in Figure 4 were compared with the DLCDv2 class recorded during the same year as the <em>in situ</em> data were collected . Cells highlighted in green in the table above represent a match between the in situ data and the DLCDv2 class. Cells highlighted in yellow represent land covers were the DLCDv2 class was similar (but not the same) as the <em>in situ</em> data. For example irrigated cropping is ?similar? to rainfed cropping. Cells highlighted in red were a mismatch between the <em>in situ</em> data and the DLCDv2 class, for example irrigated cropping is a ?mismatch? for ?tussock grasses ? open?. For 22,645 in situ data points recorded, 31% were a match with the DLCDv2 class, 53% were similar and 17% were a mismatch. This fuzzy approach to accuracy assessment was used to address the challenges of assessing a land cover classification with the best available <em>in situ</em> data, as distinct from <em>in situ</em> data that was collected with the express purpose of assessing the accuracy of an EO land cover classification (Foody 1996). Classes for which no <em>in situ</em> data were available (sugar cane, extraction sites, built-up surface) are not included in the accuracy assessment.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 classification is discriminating the managed land cover classes (in total) from the unmanaged land cover classes with a high degree of accuracy, however there is confusion between the managed classes. For example many of the areas labelled as rainfed cropping in the <em>in situ</em> data are captured as irrigated cropping in the DLCDv2 classification. Based on the in situ data the DLCDv2 the extent of grasses is being undersestimated (low producers accuracy indicating errors of omission (Table 2) and the extent of shrubs is being overestimated (low users accuracy indicating errors of commision). The producers and users accuracy for trees are both &gt;60% indicating a reasonable accuracy for tree cover. However the accuracy for specific tree cover classes (closed versus open) is lower, therefore caution should be exercised in assessing the extent of a specific canopy cover class.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Nadir- looking observations: Earth observing instruments on satellites typically record the dominant cover type rather than the tallest cover type, as a consequence of their nadir-looking configuration. The tallest stratum is used in the ISO classification and the vegetation classification schemes used to capture the <em>in-situ</em> data. As a result, changes in the dominant cover type (for example grasses in savannah ecosystems) may have a larger influence on the EVI signal than changes in taller strata (such as trees in a savannah ecosystem). This means that the DLCDv2 is likely to represent the ?Dominant cover type per epoch? rather than the ?Tallest cover type per epoch?.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Land cover classes that are poorly characterised by EVI: Land cover classes that are difficult to characterise using EVI time series include mines, urban areas, irrigated and rainfed sugar cane. These classes are included in the DLCDv2 for the purposes of providing a complete suite of land cover classes, however variation in the extent of these classes is not well captured using EVI and a single spatial extent is applied to all epochs for these classes. As a consequence users who wish to track the change in extent of these classes should refer to alternate data sources. EVI does not discriminate well between inland waters and salt lakes. For detailed information about the spatial extent of surface water please refer to Water Observations from Space at: <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs">http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs</a>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Persistent green pastures: During periods of higher rainfall the pastures-rainfed class can display similar EVI characteristics to trees-open (persistent high EVI). These classes are discriminated using a 500-metre resolution green reflectance product. This means that changes at the interface between rainfed pastures and open forests may not be detected, and that some afforestion activities may not be detected.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Spatial scale limitations: The 250-metre spatial resolution of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. The two-year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short-lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two- year period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Time scale limitations: Whilst the EVI product is available from 2000 onwards, the first map of the DLCDv2 series starts at January 2002. The land cover results for period January 2000 through to December 2001 are impacted by a lack of pre-existing 250-metre scale information about the land cover in the year 2000. As a consequence they are not included in the DLCDv2.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Terrain shadow: Areas that are affected by terrain shadow at the time of image acquisition will show anomolous results in some instances. Areas with deep shadows in winter may occaisonally be misclassified as alpine grasses and sedges. This is a known artefact and will appear scattered along areas corresponding to valley bottoms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Severe bushfires: Severe bushfires such as those that occurred on Black Saturday 2009 and the Canberra fire storm in 2003 create unusual EVI responses within a 2-year interval. As a result the land cover class in the map interval following the major fire may be inaccurate. Care should be used when interpreting the land cover maps in areas that have been subject to severe fire.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purposes of the DLCDv2.1 product are to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding and reporting on land cover change, and to assist policy makers to assess how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the ABS Land Accounts.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 as a model input parameter. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. The DLCDv2 product suite provides standardised land cover datasets for Australia using innovative time series analysis techniques to classify each pixel based on the way that pixel has behaved over a two year period. Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</p>

<p>Each map has been generated by applying a sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data. The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined below.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. The DLCDv2 product suite provides standardised land cover datasets for Australia using innovative time series analysis techniques to classify each pixel based on the way that pixel has behaved over a two year period. Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</p>

<p>Each map has been generated by applying a sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data. The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined below.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

attempting match on: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Dynamic land cover shows how Australian land cover is changing over time.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Dynamic land cover shows how Australian land cover is changing over time.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset comprises a land cover classification showing the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia. The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2001 to 2015. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>The current release of the second version DLCDv2.1 (described in this document) presents land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country for the two year intervals listed in the table below. It consists of maps based on 2 years of MODIS EVI time-series data. The date ranges for each of the map series are:</p>

<ol>
	<li>January 2001-December 2002</li>
	<li>January 2002-December 2003</li>
	<li>January 2003-December 2004</li>
	<li>January 2004-December 2005</li>
	<li>January 2005-December 2006</li>
	<li>January 2006-December 2007</li>
	<li>January 2007-December 2008</li>
	<li>January 2008-December 2009</li>
	<li>January 2009-December 2010</li>
	<li>January 2010-December 2011</li>
	<li>January 2011-December 2012</li>
	<li>January 2012-December 2013</li>
	<li>January 2013-December 2014</li>
	<li>January 2014-December 2015</li>
</ol>

<p>DLCD can be used as an input for a wide range of environmental modelling applications, including:<br />
? Climate<br />
? Wind and water erosion risk<br />
? Evapotranspiration<br />
? Carbon dynamics<br />
? Land surface processes<br />
? Inundation.</p>

<p>In conjunction with trends in annual Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret land use change.</p>

<p>The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Standards Organisation (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The Dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 22 classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as closed forest and open grasslands.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset comprises a land cover classification showing the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia. The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2001 to 2015. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>The current release of the second version DLCDv2.1 (described in this document) presents land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country for the two year intervals listed in the table below. It consists of maps based on 2 years of MODIS EVI time-series data. The date ranges for each of the map series are:</p>

<ol>
	<li>January 2001-December 2002</li>
	<li>January 2002-December 2003</li>
	<li>January 2003-December 2004</li>
	<li>January 2004-December 2005</li>
	<li>January 2005-December 2006</li>
	<li>January 2006-December 2007</li>
	<li>January 2007-December 2008</li>
	<li>January 2008-December 2009</li>
	<li>January 2009-December 2010</li>
	<li>January 2010-December 2011</li>
	<li>January 2011-December 2012</li>
	<li>January 2012-December 2013</li>
	<li>January 2013-December 2014</li>
	<li>January 2014-December 2015</li>
</ol>

? Climate<br />
? Wind and water erosion risk<br />
? Evapotranspiration<br />
? Carbon dynamics<br />
? Land surface processes<br />
? Inundation.</p>

<p>In conjunction with trends in annual Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret land use change.</p>

<p>The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Standards Organisation (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). No match node contents append: </field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</value><end_value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type>

attempting match on: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-13T03:01:00</value><end_value>2017-06-13T03:01:00</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_publishing_entity><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-13T03:01:00</value><end_value>2017-06-13T03:01:00</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact>
attempting match on: %!67%!
No match node contents append: %!67%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</value><end_value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The maps series are being validated using over 22,000 field sites provided by Federal, State and Territory Government agencies collected over the period 2001 to 2012 (Figure 4) including data contributed from these sources:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resouce Economics and Sciences (ABARES) Riverina Plains Data</li>
	<li>Australian Agricultural and Grazing Industries Survey (AAGIS)</li>
	<li>Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Colleambally Data</li>
	<li>Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF) rapid assesment sites</li>
	<li>New South Wales Land Practices</li>
	<li>Queensland Herbarium CorVeg</li>
	<li>Sunrise21</li>
	<li>Victorian State Forest Resouce Inventory (SFRI) field data</li>
	<li>Victorian Land Use Information System (VLUIS)</li>
	<li>Western Australian Department of Environment and Conservation</li>
	<li>Western Australian WARM</li>
</ul>

These standard information products deliver International Standards Organisation (ISO) compliant land cover maps across the Australian landmass. The datasets provide a consistent series of maps that show how Australian land cover is changing over time. The current version consists of 14 maps each based on 2 years of MODIS data. The 14 maps cover the period from January 2001 ? December 2015.</p>

	-<uuid><value>f0f8893f-d31d-4e0c-809a-76e3d432f5b0</value></uuid><vid><value>167</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_250_2.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489546860</value></created><changed><value>1489709349</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489709349</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-8d025ebab2f6c118bdb6d77387a0668b</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The <em>in situ</em> data shown in Figure 4 were compared with the DLCDv2 class recorded during the same year as the <em>in situ</em> data were collected . Cells highlighted in green in the table above represent a match between the in situ data and the DLCDv2 class. Cells highlighted in yellow represent land covers were the DLCDv2 class was similar (but not the same) as the <em>in situ</em> data. For example irrigated cropping is ?similar? to rainfed cropping. Cells highlighted in red were a mismatch between the <em>in situ</em> data and the DLCDv2 class, for example irrigated cropping is a ?mismatch? for ?tussock grasses ? open?. For 22,645 in situ data points recorded, 31% were a match with the DLCDv2 class, 53% were similar and 17% were a mismatch. This fuzzy approach to accuracy assessment was used to address the challenges of assessing a land cover classification with the best available <em>in situ</em> data, as distinct from <em>in situ</em> data that was collected with the express purpose of assessing the accuracy of an EO land cover classification (Foody 1996). Classes for which no <em>in situ</em> data were available (sugar cane, extraction sites, built-up surface) are not included in the accuracy assessment.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 classification is discriminating the managed land cover classes (in total) from the unmanaged land cover classes with a high degree of accuracy, however there is confusion between the managed classes. For example many of the areas labelled as rainfed cropping in the <em>in situ</em> data are captured as irrigated cropping in the DLCDv2 classification. Based on the in situ data the DLCDv2 the extent of grasses is being undersestimated (low producers accuracy indicating errors of omission (Table 2) and the extent of shrubs is being overestimated (low users accuracy indicating errors of commision). The producers and users accuracy for trees are both &gt;60% indicating a reasonable accuracy for tree cover. However the accuracy for specific tree cover classes (closed versus open) is lower, therefore caution should be exercised in assessing the extent of a specific canopy cover class.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Nadir- looking observations: Earth observing instruments on satellites typically record the dominant cover type rather than the tallest cover type, as a consequence of their nadir-looking configuration. The tallest stratum is used in the ISO classification and the vegetation classification schemes used to capture the <em>in-situ</em> data. As a result, changes in the dominant cover type (for example grasses in savannah ecosystems) may have a larger influence on the EVI signal than changes in taller strata (such as trees in a savannah ecosystem). This means that the DLCDv2 is likely to represent the ?Dominant cover type per epoch? rather than the ?Tallest cover type per epoch?.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Land cover classes that are poorly characterised by EVI: Land cover classes that are difficult to characterise using EVI time series include mines, urban areas, irrigated and rainfed sugar cane. These classes are included in the DLCDv2 for the purposes of providing a complete suite of land cover classes, however variation in the extent of these classes is not well captured using EVI and a single spatial extent is applied to all epochs for these classes. As a consequence users who wish to track the change in extent of these classes should refer to alternate data sources. EVI does not discriminate well between inland waters and salt lakes. For detailed information about the spatial extent of surface water please refer to Water Observations from Space at: <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs">http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs</a>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Persistent green pastures: During periods of higher rainfall the pastures-rainfed class can display similar EVI characteristics to trees-open (persistent high EVI). These classes are discriminated using a 500-metre resolution green reflectance product. This means that changes at the interface between rainfed pastures and open forests may not be detected, and that some afforestion activities may not be detected.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Spatial scale limitations: The 250-metre spatial resolution of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. The two-year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short-lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two- year period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Time scale limitations: Whilst the EVI product is available from 2000 onwards, the first map of the DLCDv2 series starts at January 2002. The land cover results for period January 2000 through to December 2001 are impacted by a lack of pre-existing 250-metre scale information about the land cover in the year 2000. As a consequence they are not included in the DLCDv2.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Terrain shadow: Areas that are affected by terrain shadow at the time of image acquisition will show anomolous results in some instances. Areas with deep shadows in winter may occaisonally be misclassified as alpine grasses and sedges. This is a known artefact and will appear scattered along areas corresponding to valley bottoms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Severe bushfires: Severe bushfires such as those that occurred on Black Saturday 2009 and the Canberra fire storm in 2003 create unusual EVI responses within a 2-year interval. As a result the land cover class in the map interval following the major fire may be inaccurate. Care should be used when interpreting the land cover maps in areas that have been subject to severe fire.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purposes of the DLCDv2.1 product are to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding and reporting on land cover change, and to assist policy makers to assess how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the ABS Land Accounts.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 as a model input parameter. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset (DLCD) is the first nationally consistent and thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. The DLCDv2 product suite provides standardised land cover datasets for Australia using innovative time series analysis techniques to classify each pixel based on the way that pixel has behaved over a two year period. Each map can be considered in isolation, or two maps from different intervals can be compared to identify the changes in land cover that have occurred over that time frame.</p>

<p>Each map has been generated by applying a sophisticated time series analysis technique known as Dynamic Markov Chain modelling to two years of MODIS EVI data. The outputs of the time series analysis are filtered using a class change constraint matrix, a terrain mask and MODIS green albedo products. The maps contain 22 land cover classes as outlined below.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!70%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_hprm_references/><field_images><target_id>15</target_id><alt>DLCD Workflow diagram</alt><title></title><width>1531</width><height>826</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>cc0df0d5-ce13-4d7e-b9d9-d4c6e5840992</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/DLCD_Figure_1_0.png</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>16</target_id><alt>Illustration of the construction of DLCD output from individual time slices.</alt><title></title><width>895</width><height>632</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>74cde89d-3b69-4a1b-b9fe-ea7902f770a1</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/DLCD_Figure_2_0.jpg</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>17</target_id><alt>Examples of DLCD output for different year ranges.</alt><title></title><width>2481</width><height>3506</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>79d25f29-ac47-47e6-b0e7-deed85d4120e</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/DLCD_Figure_3_0.png</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>18</target_id><alt>DLCD validation point locations.</alt><title></title><width>4962</width><height>3509</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>411c9b9f-a5e7-42a9-a7c2-a8930529456c</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/DLCD_Figure_4_0.png</url></field_images><field_ingestion_contact>

	-%!6915%!
	-</field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>Dynamic land cover shows how Australian land cover is changing over time.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Dynamic Land Cover Dataset comprises a land cover classification showing the change in behaviour of land cover across Australia. The DLCD includes data for every 250m by 250m area for the period 2001 to 2015. It provides a basis for reporting on change and trends in vegetation cover and extent. Information about land cover dynamics is essential to understanding and addressing a range of national challenges such as drought, salinity, water availability and ecosystem health.</p>

<p>The current release of the second version DLCDv2.1 (described in this document) presents land cover information for every 250m by 250m area of the country for the two year intervals listed in the table below. It consists of maps based on 2 years of MODIS EVI time-series data. The date ranges for each of the map series are:</p>

<ol>
	<li>January 2001-December 2002</li>
	<li>January 2002-December 2003</li>
	<li>January 2003-December 2004</li>
	<li>January 2004-December 2005</li>
	<li>January 2005-December 2006</li>
	<li>January 2006-December 2007</li>
	<li>January 2007-December 2008</li>
	<li>January 2008-December 2009</li>
	<li>January 2009-December 2010</li>
	<li>January 2010-December 2011</li>
	<li>January 2011-December 2012</li>
	<li>January 2012-December 2013</li>
	<li>January 2013-December 2014</li>
	<li>January 2014-December 2015</li>
</ol>

<p>DLCD can be used as an input for a wide range of environmental modelling applications, including:<br />
? Climate<br />
? Wind and water erosion risk<br />
? Evapotranspiration<br />
? Carbon dynamics<br />
? Land surface processes<br />
? Inundation.</p>

<p>In conjunction with trends in annual Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data, the DLCD can be used to identify emerging patterns of land cover change and provide a spatial and historical context within which to interpret land use change.</p>

<p>The classification scheme used to describe land cover categories in the Dataset conforms to the 2007 International Standards Organisation (ISO) land cover standard (19144-2). The Dataset shows Australian land covers clustered into 22 classes. These reflect the structural character of vegetation, ranging from cultivated and managed land covers (crops and pastures) to natural land covers such as closed forest and open grasslands.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</value><end_value>2017-03-15T03:01:00</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type>

	-%!67%!

<ul>
	<li>Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resouce Economics and Sciences (ABARES) Riverina Plains Data</li>
	<li>Australian Agricultural and Grazing Industries Survey (AAGIS)</li>
	<li>Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Colleambally Data</li>

These standard information products deliver International Standards Organisation (ISO) compliant land cover maps across the Australian landmass. The datasets provide a consistent series of maps that show how Australian land cover is changing over time. The current version consists of 14 maps each based on 2 years of MODIS data. match node contents append: <nid><value>86</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>4b587cdc-d471-4461-a5c9-630810a57370</value></uuid><vid><value>151</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488762134</value></created><changed><value>1488762291</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488762291</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-7dda954684f63f804e7f83ff2cc6c05e</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc</uri><title>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>001df937-295d-48cc-9ab6-abd623eb4840</value></uuid><vid><value>157</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489546067</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489546067</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>6-fc4a2c6b6fa1b8fb08b46a415b2fa0ba</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>001df937-295d-48cc-9ab6-abd623eb4840</value></uuid><vid><value>157</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489546067</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489546067</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>6-fc4a2c6b6fa1b8fb08b46a415b2fa0ba</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><uri>https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index</uri><title>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia.</title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140</uri><title><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. ?Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction ? the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 Janu]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119</uri><title><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. ?Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011.]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for each cover fraction.</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of green cover and 'barest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of bare soil that occurred within the compositing period.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents><uri>https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index</uri><title>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia.</title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140</uri><title><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. ?Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction ? the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 Janu]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119</uri><title><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. ?Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011.]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for each cover fraction.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

No match node contents append: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of fractional cover. The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC-STATS_25 provides fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010).
