The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. 	-<uuid><value>001df937-295d-48cc-9ab6-abd623eb4840</value></uuid><vid><value>157</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489546067</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489546067</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>6-fc4a2c6b6fa1b8fb08b46a415b2fa0ba</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><uri>https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index</uri><title>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia.</title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140</uri><title><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. ?Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction ? the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 Janu]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119</uri><title><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. ?Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011.]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental composites for each cover fraction.</p>

<p>The percentile ranges for each compositing period can be used to identify the 'greenest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of green cover and 'barest' observation i.e. 90th percentile of bare soil that occurred within the compositing period.</p>

<p>The 10th and 90th percentile are used in preference to the minimum and maximum values because they are less prone to residual noise associated with undetected cloud/cloud shadow. The 50th percentile (median) are used in preference to the mean as the median is less prone to being skewed by extreme values. It is worth noting that some undetected cloud and cloud shadow artefacts may still be present in the 10th and 90th percentiles, especially in areas with frequent cloud cover such as the wet tropics and Tasmania.</p>

<p>To account for satellite availability and status the statistics are calculated using the following satellites for the following periods of time:<br />
1987-1998 : Landsat 5<br />
1999 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2000-2002 : Landsat 7<br />
2003 : Landsat 5 and Landsat 7<br />
2004-2010 : Landsat 5<br />
2011-2012 : Landsat 7<br />
2013 onward : Landsat 8</p>

<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!70%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_hprm_references><value>D2014-213964</value></field_hprm_references><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact>
	-%!66%!
	-</field_ingestion_contact><field_license>
	-%!6718%!
	-</field_license><field_maintenance/><field_maintenance_contact>
	-%!66%!
	-</field_maintenance_contact><field_media_contact>
	-%!69%!
	-</field_media_contact><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-05T00:04:35</value><end_value>2017-05-05T00:04:35</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact>
	-%!68%!
	-</field_metadata_contact><field_nci_for_codes>
	-%!6914%!
	-</field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>This product provides continental seasonal (most recent 8 seasons) and annual (each calendar year from 1987 to present) statistical (10th, 50th and 90th percentile) summaries of fractional cover. The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC-STATS_25 provides fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
	-%!65%!

The fractional cover statistics are calculated from the fractional cover product (FC_25_2.0.0)</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_use_constraints><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>
matches: [0] = <nid><value>85 [1] = nid [2] = 85
match node contents append: <nid><value>85</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>ae67a355-6435-40c3-918f-0566e39c041c</value></uuid><vid><value>156</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489446198</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489446198</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>5-4ca758b3bc5ac6b56257aefd15cc173e</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>ae67a355-6435-40c3-918f-0566e39c041c</value></uuid><vid><value>156</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489446198</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489446198</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>5-4ca758b3bc5ac6b56257aefd15cc173e</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>

No match node contents append: </field_nci_for_codes><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>

No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

attempting match on: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>
No match node contents append: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

	-<nid><value>85</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>ae67a355-6435-40c3-918f-0566e39c041c</value></uuid><vid><value>156</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489446198</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489446198</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>5-4ca758b3bc5ac6b56257aefd15cc173e</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents><uri>https://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/u39/public/html/modis/fractionalcover-sitedata-abares/index</uri><title>ABARES, 2014 Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014. Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences, Canberra, Australia.</title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455672/15arspc-Submission-140</uri><title><![CDATA[Scarth, P., Roder, A. and Schmidt, M., 2010. ?Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction ? the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 Janu]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_documents><uri>http://www.scribd.com/doc/37455826/15arspc-Submission-119</uri><title><![CDATA[Schmidt, M., Denham, R. and Scarth, P., 2010. ?Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland?, Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing & Photogrammetry Conference, viewed 4 January 2011.]]></title><options/></field_documents><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>79676</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>To maintain compatibility with the Joint Remote Sensing Research Programs Fractional Cover product the values for this product are scaled as follows:<br />
For the fractional cover bands (PV, NPV, BS)<br />
0-100 = no data values<br />
101-200 = fractional cover values that range between 1 and 100%</p>

<p>For example an area that has green (photosynthetic) vegetation cover of 50% would have a PV value of 150<br />
For the unmixing error (UE) band, the values are scaled as per the JRSRP product.</p>

	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>

	-%!86%!
	-</field_software_dependencies><field_subject_matter_experts>
	-%!5%!
	-</field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional Cover (FC) is one of two vegetation-related products currently offered by the AGDC, the other being the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) product. FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>
	-%!6697%!

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_use_constraints><field_version_number><value>2.0.0</value></field_version_number><field_websites/>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>67daa768-b40f-4ee7-86af-767f569fe949</value></uuid><vid><value>143</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Full pass/strip processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488754542</value></created><changed><value>1488754595</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488754595</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-5b841210a005d23f37b12e3e7737fa81</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>(See technical report and reference papers http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA20164.pdf)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>?Full pass? or 'strip' processing rectifies a sequential strip of images taken during a single segment of a satellite?s orbit. the metadata for each separate scene are merged to produce a single, continuous set of orbit and attitude parameters, such that the entire strip of tens of images can be treated as a single image, even though the separate scenes are not actually merged. The merging of orbit data results in a considerable reduction in both the number of unknown orientation parameters and the number of control points required in the sensor orientation adjustment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>?Full pass? or 'strip' processing rectifies a sequential strip of images taken during a single segment of a satellite?s orbit. the metadata for each separate scene are merged to produce a single, continuous set of orbit and attitude parameters, such that the entire strip of tens of images can be treated as a single image, even though the separate scenes are not actually merged. The merging of orbit data results in a considerable reduction in both the number of unknown orientation parameters and the number of control points required in the sensor orientation adjustment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

attempting match on: <uuid><value>56a576f7-38eb-4622-abfb-c5378d3788f6</value></uuid><vid><value>148</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488517982</value></created><changed><value>1488757785</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488757785</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>3-daaba2428c3e3b999b26b7d0b599ab0a</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image 2.5m</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Reference image ? image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />
Basemap ? feature revision and verification, reference layer</p>

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government ? Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Geographic Reference Image (AGRI) is a consistent and accurate reference image for rectification of imagery from multiple sources at resolutions of 2.5 metres or less. The AGRI is needed because the emerging new satellites and other sources of imagery will generate increasing amounts of data. The AGRI can ensure that images from these sources are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information.</p>

<p>During compilation more than 9560 satellite scenes, totalling over 6 terabytes, were used to produce eight mosaics, covering each of Australia's Universal Transverse Mercator map zones. These mosaics were then combined to produce a single mosaic covering the Australian continent. Intensity and contrast balancing were used to ensure visual consistency across the mosaic while maintaining the dynamic range of the image.</p>

<p>The AGRI was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, international collaboration, the Australian spatial information industry, and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia. Japan's Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) made possible the complete coverage of high quality imagery, which forms the foundation of the AGRI, as well as accurate data on the satellite orbit. Geoscience Australia was an international collaborator on the ALOS; handling data for the Oceania region. The Barista software, developed by the Cooperative Research Centre for Spatial Information, made the project feasible in terms of time, logistics, and cost. Barista reduced the image registration problem from correction of almost 10 000 scenes to correction of just 105 orbit segments (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The expertise and capability of the Australian spatial information industry was used in the design of GIS databases to manage the survey data and to conduct the many field surveys to remote areas of Australia. The expertise and capabilities of Geoscience Australia staff in both Earth observation and geodesy were also essential inputs to the project (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The AGRI provides a consistent base image which will be an important foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators. The AGRI mosaic and associated datasets are available to the public under the Creative Commons-Attribution licensing terms at cost of transfer from Geoscience Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The data set is replicated at GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>56a576f7-38eb-4622-abfb-c5378d3788f6</value></uuid><vid><value>148</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488517982</value></created><changed><value>1488757785</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488757785</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>3-daaba2428c3e3b999b26b7d0b599ab0a</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image 2.5m</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Reference image ? image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government ? Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>

	-<uuid><value>56a576f7-38eb-4622-abfb-c5378d3788f6</value></uuid><vid><value>148</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488517982</value></created><changed><value>1488757785</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488757785</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>3-daaba2428c3e3b999b26b7d0b599ab0a</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image 2.5m</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Reference image ? image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />
Basemap ? feature revision and verification, reference layer</p>

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government ? Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Geographic Reference Image (AGRI) is a consistent and accurate reference image for rectification of imagery from multiple sources at resolutions of 2.5 metres or less. The AGRI is needed because the emerging new satellites and other sources of imagery will generate increasing amounts of data. The AGRI can ensure that images from these sources are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information.</p>

<p>During compilation more than 9560 satellite scenes, totalling over 6 terabytes, were used to produce eight mosaics, covering each of Australia's Universal Transverse Mercator map zones. These mosaics were then combined to produce a single mosaic covering the Australian continent. Intensity and contrast balancing were used to ensure visual consistency across the mosaic while maintaining the dynamic range of the image.</p>

<p>The AGRI was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, international collaboration, the Australian spatial information industry, and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia. Japan's Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) made possible the complete coverage of high quality imagery, which forms the foundation of the AGRI, as well as accurate data on the satellite orbit. Geoscience Australia was an international collaborator on the ALOS; handling data for the Oceania region. The Barista software, developed by the Cooperative Research Centre for Spatial Information, made the project feasible in terms of time, logistics, and cost. Barista reduced the image registration problem from correction of almost 10 000 scenes to correction of just 105 orbit segments (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The expertise and capability of the Australian spatial information industry was used in the design of GIS databases to manage the survey data and to conduct the many field surveys to remote areas of Australia. The expertise and capabilities of Geoscience Australia staff in both Earth observation and geodesy were also essential inputs to the project (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The AGRI provides a consistent base image which will be an important foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators. The AGRI mosaic and associated datasets are available to the public under the Creative Commons-Attribution licensing terms at cost of transfer from Geoscience Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The data set is replicated at GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

match node contents append: <nid><value>73</value></nid>
attempting match on: <uuid><value>29c46cb7-b7ae-4c9d-b6ec-f63df56e268e</value></uuid><vid><value>139</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488434202</value></created><changed><value>1488517789</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488517789</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-358bf8ab14b5581b997bd81c71b7a7e0</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>None</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>29c46cb7-b7ae-4c9d-b6ec-f63df56e268e</value></uuid><vid><value>139</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488434202</value></created><changed><value>1488517789</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488517789</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-358bf8ab14b5581b997bd81c71b7a7e0</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>

attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The PQ25 product facilitates interpretation and processing of Surface Reflectance (SR-N/NT), Fractional Cover 25 (FC25) and all derivative products.<br />
PQ25 is an assessment of each image pixel to determine if it is an unobscured, unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and also whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. The PQ product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude pixels which don?t meet their quality criteria from analysis . The capacity to automatically exclude such pixels is essential for emerging multi-temporal analysis techniques that make use of every quality assured pixel within a time series of observations.</p>

<p>Users can choose to process only land pixels, or only sea pixels depending on their analytical requirements, leading to enhanced computationally efficient.</p>

Adding node contents to map with id: 73
	-<nid><value>73</value></nid>
	-<uuid><value>29c46cb7-b7ae-4c9d-b6ec-f63df56e268e</value></uuid><vid><value>139</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488434202</value></created><changed><value>1488517789</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488517789</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-358bf8ab14b5581b997bd81c71b7a7e0</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>None</p>
