attempting match on: <uuid><value>57b07479-f465-4f91-9db2-a7f513e5153a</value></uuid><vid><value>123</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR-NT_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488243004</value></created><changed><value>1488431983</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488431983</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>11-9ed2987c94b3f644f72c1a35b6a1c5c2</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 v. 2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
No match node contents append: <uuid><value>57b07479-f465-4f91-9db2-a7f513e5153a</value></uuid><vid><value>123</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>0</value></status><title><value>SR-NT_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488243004</value></created><changed><value>1488431983</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488431983</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>11-9ed2987c94b3f644f72c1a35b6a1c5c2</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 v. 2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>Terrain affects optical satellite images through both irradiance and bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) effects. Slopes facing the sun receive enhanced solar irradiance and appear brighter compared to those facing away from the sun. For anisotropic surfaces, the radiance received at the satellite sensor from a sloping surface is also affected by surface BRDF which varies with combinations of surface landcover types, sun, and satellite geometry (sun and sensor view, and their relative azimuth angle) as well as topographic geometry (primarily slope and aspect angles). Consequently, to obtain comparable surface reflectance from satellite images covering mountainous areas, it is necessary to process the images to reduce or remove the topographic effect so that the images can be used for different purposes on the same spectral base. A Digital Surface Model (DSM) resolution appropriate to the scale of the resolution of satellite image is needed for the best results. 1 second SRTM DSM is used for NBART processing.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>Terrain affects optical satellite images through both irradiance and bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) effects. Slopes facing the sun receive enhanced solar irradiance and appear brighter compared to those facing away from the sun. For anisotropic surfaces, the radiance received at the satellite sensor from a sloping surface is also affected by surface BRDF which varies with combinations of surface landcover types, sun, and satellite geometry (sun and sensor view, and their relative azimuth angle) as well as topographic geometry (primarily slope and aspect angles). Consequently, to obtain comparable surface reflectance from satellite images covering mountainous areas, it is necessary to process the images to reduce or remove the topographic effect so that the images can be used for different purposes on the same spectral base. A Digital Surface Model (DSM) resolution appropriate to the scale of the resolution of satellite image is needed for the best results. 1 second SRTM DSM is used for NBART processing.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>

attempting match on: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance product is an algorithm that has been applied to all satellite imagery in the Landsat archive since 1987 that corrects each image to account for variations due to atmospheric properties, sun position and sensor view angle when the imagery was captured. This is undertaken to allow comparison of imagery acquired at different times, by different sensors, in different seasons and in different geographic regions. These products also indicate whether the imagery has been affected by cloud or cloud shadow, contains missing data or has been affected in other ways. The Surface Reflectance products are useful as a fundamental starting point for any further analysis and are the underlying data of all other AGDC products.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>

This is undertaken to allow comparison of imagery acquired at different times, by different sensors, in different seasons and in different geographic regions. These products also indicate whether the imagery has been affected by cloud or cloud shadow, contains missing data or has been affected in other ways. The Surface Reflectance products are useful as a fundamental starting point for any further analysis and are the underlying data of all other AGDC products.</p>

attempting match on: <nid><value>37</value></nid>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 v. 2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>75062</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>Terrain affects optical satellite images through both irradiance and bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) effects. Slopes facing the sun receive enhanced solar irradiance and appear brighter compared to those facing away from the sun. For anisotropic surfaces, the radiance received at the satellite sensor from a sloping surface is also affected by surface BRDF which varies with combinations of surface landcover types, sun, and satellite geometry (sun and sensor view, and their relative azimuth angle) as well as topographic geometry (primarily slope and aspect angles). Consequently, to obtain comparable surface reflectance from satellite images covering mountainous areas, it is necessary to process the images to reduce or remove the topographic effect so that the images can be used for different purposes on the same spectral base. A Digital Surface Model (DSM) resolution appropriate to the scale of the resolution of satellite image is needed for the best results. 1 second SRTM DSM is used for NBART processing.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
	-%!70%!
	-</field_feedback_contact><field_hprm_references><value>D2013-175180</value></field_hprm_references><field_images><target_id>3</target_id><alt>Example satellite image</alt><title></title><width>1001</width><height>1201</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>2aa6aec2-52be-499a-827e-ad3c62549f1b</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/ARG25_Figure_1.jpg</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>4</target_id><alt>Tile coverage of Australia</alt><title></title><width>584</width><height>427</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>4101befe-bcab-4679-abfa-bc216c983db2</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/ARG25_Figure_2.jpg</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>5</target_id><alt>Path and row counts</alt><title></title><width>882</width><height>498</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>e1fe0d2b-7a58-4812-b510-d665f170b462</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/ARG25_Figure_3.jpg</url></field_images><field_images><target_id>7</target_id><alt>Comparison of reflectance with and without terrain effects.</alt><title></title><width>662</width><height>251</height><target_type>file</target_type><target_uuid>c28a1b6c-1f2a-49ff-98e3-93fe62f2455e</target_uuid><url>http://52.64.197.68/sites/default/files/2017-03/ARG25_Figure_6.jpg</url></field_images><field_ingestion_contact>

SR-NT corrects for terrain shadow.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>

	-%!5%!
	-</field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance product is an algorithm that has been applied to all satellite imagery in the Landsat archive since 1987 that corrects each image to account for variations due to atmospheric properties, sun position and sensor view angle when the imagery was captured. This is undertaken to allow comparison of imagery acquired at different times, by different sensors, in different seasons and in different geographic regions. These products also indicate whether the imagery has been affected by cloud or cloud shadow, contains missing data or has been affected in other ways. The Surface Reflectance products are useful as a fundamental starting point for any further analysis and are the underlying data of all other AGDC products.</p>

GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />

? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

attempting match on: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_data_source_contact><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity>
attempting match on: %!64%!
No match node contents append: %!64%!
attempting match on: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>102288</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>102288</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>

No match node contents append: </field_metadata_contact><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code><value>rs0</value></field_nci_project_code><field_one_line_summary><value>The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity>
attempting match on: %!65%!
No match node contents append: %!65%!
attempting match on: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
No match node contents append: </field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
attempting match on: %!65%!

attempting match on: </field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors><value>Fuqin Li</value><format>basic_html</format></field_principal_contributors><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</value><end_value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>
No match node contents append: </field_principal_contact><field_principal_contributors><value>Fuqin Li</value><format>basic_html</format></field_principal_contributors><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</value><end_value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity>

attempting match on: %!67%!
No match node contents append: %!67%!
attempting match on: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</value><end_value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>
No match node contents append: </field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</value><end_value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). attempting match on: %!6725%!
No match node contents append: %!6725%!
attempting match on: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_software_dependencies>
No match node contents append: </field_security_classification><field_services/><field_simple_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+</value><format>basic_html</format></field_simple_title><field_software_dependencies>
attempting match on: %!63%!
No match node contents append: %!63%!
attempting match on: </field_software_dependencies><field_subject_matter_experts>
No match node contents append: </field_software_dependencies><field_subject_matter_experts>
attempting match on: %!5%!
No match node contents append: %!5%!
attempting match on: </field_subject_matter_experts><field_summary><value><![CDATA[<p>The Surface Reflectance product has been corrected to account for variations caused by atmospheric properties, sun position and sensor view angle at time of image capture. These corrections have been applied to all satellite imagery in the Landsat archive since 1987. This is undertaken to allow comparison of imagery acquired at different times, by different sensors, in different seasons and in different geographic locations. These products also indicate where the imagery has been affected by cloud or cloud shadow, contains missing data or has been affected in other ways. The Surface Reflectance products are useful as a fundamental starting point for any further analysis and are the underlying data of all other AGDC products.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_summary><field_tables/><field_update_frequency>

	-<uuid><value>f045e199-f08a-4a50-93ea-c15b9fdc6bd8</value></uuid><vid><value>267</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR-N_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488243004</value></created><changed><value>1492995781</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1492995781</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>17-9936b4d07d52bf898b955ee5ff62a084</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 v. 2</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

	-%!64%!
	-</field_distribution_entity><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id><value>102288</value></field_ecat_id><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The standardised SR data products deliver calibrated optical surface reflectance data across land and coastal fringes. SR is a medium resolution (~25 m) grid based on the Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI archive and presents surface reflectance data in 25 m? grid cells.</p>

<p>Radiance measurements from EO sensors do not directly quantify the surface reflectance of the Earth. Such measurements are modified by variations in atmospheric properties, sun position, sensor view angle, surface slope and surface aspect. To obtain consistent and comparable measures of Earth surface reflectance from EO, these variations need to be reduced or removed from the radiance measurements (Li et al., 2010). This is especially important when comparing imagery acquired in different seasons and geographic regions.</p>

<p>The SR product is created using a physics-based, coupled BRDF and atmospheric correction model that can be applied to both flat and inclined surfaces (Li et al., 2012). The resulting surface reflectance values are comparable both within individual images and between images acquired at different times and/or with different sensors.</p>

<p>This product does not include terrain illumination reflectance correction (see SR-NT_25)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact>

	-%!65%!
	-</field_ordering_entity><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>Surface Reflectance (SR) is a suite of Earth Observation (EO) products from GA. The SR product suite provides standardised optical surface reflectance datasets using robust physical models to correct for variations in image radiance values due to atmospheric properties, and sun and sensor geometry. The resulting stack of surface reflectance grids are consistent over space and time which is instrumental in identifying and quantifying environmental change. SR is based on radiance data from the Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI sensors.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact>
	-%!65%!

	-%!67%!
	-</field_qa_contact><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</value><end_value>2017-02-28T00:50:04</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate combined atmospheric and surface BRDF correction using field reflectance measurements at two very different sites, Gwydir, NSW, and Lake Frome, SA?correlation (measured as r) between corrected image values and field data was &gt; 0.95.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Validate surface BRDF correction using data from image overlap areas of adjacent paths acquired one week apart in northeast Queensland?normalised reflectance factor was very close in corrected images, but not in original images, and difference in reflectance factor values between corrected and uncorrected images can be &gt; 0.05.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Cross-validate Landsat TM data for accuracy of spectral reflectance using the MODIS reflectance product for Lake Frome?correlation (measured as r2) between corrected Landsat TM image values and MODIS reflectance product was 0.93?0.97 in all bands except Landsat TM band 5, which was 0.90.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic Correction As detailed in Li et al. (2012), two high relief areas in southeast Australia (Australian Alps in northeast Victoria and the Blue Mountains in NSW) were used to test the algorithm against eight Landsat images with varying solar angles (seasons), and terrain types.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Visual assessment showed that the algorithm removed much of the topographic effect and detected deep shadows in all eight images. An indirect validation based on the change in correlation between the data and terrain slope showed that the correlation coefficient between the surface reflectance factor and the cosine of the incident (sun) angle reduced dramatically after the topographic correction algorithm was applied. The correlation coefficient typically reduced from 0.80?0.70 to 0.05 in areas of significant relief. It was also shown how the corrected surface reflectance can provide suitable input data for multi-temporal land cover classification in areas of high relief based on spectral signatures and spectral albedo, while the products based only on BRDF and atmospheric correction cannot. To provide comparison with previous work and to validate the proposed algorithm, two empirical methods based on the C-correction were used as well as the established sun-canopy-sensor SCS-method to provide benchmarks. The proposed method was found to achieve the same measures of shade reduction without empirical regression.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>The Geometric QA software utilises an area based image-to-image correlation technique to assess and compare the difference between the target image and the reference image at regular gridded QA points. The residual of each QA point will be derived and scene statistics such as number of valid QA points, mean residual X/Y, STD residual X/Y and CEP90 will be recorded in v2 AGDC.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Because each scene recorded in v2 AGDC will have a GQA assessment result, the ?minimum GCP number? threshold has been lowered to enable more products processed to Ortho level ? especially for coastal scenes where only a very small portion of the image contains land for GCP identification purpose.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>Product generation process is fully automated and there are checks in place to ensure that each step results in output meeting relevant product specification criteria. For example, the production system performs geometry QA before generating the final version of the product. Failed processes are rerun according to set up routines to ensure completeness of data. A sample of final data is verified manually for conformance to product specification.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_quality_assurance><value><![CDATA[<p>At the end of the process, the system generates a companion dataset, the Pixel Quality assessment (PQ25). The PQ25 is a classification that represents an assessment of whether an image pixel represents an unobscured unsaturated observation of the Earth?s surface and whether the pixel is represented in each spectral band. In particular, whether a pixel contains: ? Spectral Contiguity ? Per band saturation assessment ? Cloud detection ? Cloud shadow estimation ? Offshore (sea) ? Onshore (land) The PQ25 product allows users to produce masks which can be used to exclude affected pixels which don?t meet quality criteria from further analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_quality_assurance><field_resource_type>

attempting match on: </field_described_by><field_detailed_rq_descr><value><![CDATA[<p>The system must respect the requirement to maintain full provenance of all information inputs and outputs in the following manner:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Incorporation of new datasets into the base information must demand full provenance be provided.</li>
	<li>All statistical reports must record provenance for how results have been derived.</li>
	<li>Where automated reporting is being delivered, ensuring that full provenance for the report, as well as contributing information is recorded.</li>
</ul>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>7fe74b54-d972-446a-ac2a-bbd68fb77279</value></uuid><vid><value>269</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ARG_25_1.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1490308522</value></created><changed><value>1493007044</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1493007044</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>16</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>407af177-566e-4647-a075-36a835a27827</target_uuid><url>/user/16</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>published</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-aaae3f4304da10c4351ec918f32b7f81</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Reflectance Grid 25 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>ARG25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery over Australia for several decades and more recently Landsat OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery.<br />
To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ imagery to create the ARG25-V0.0 and ARG25-V0.1 products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes5 and processing complexities involved with production of this product. It is intended that the Landsat archives from 1987 will be incrementally incorporated into the ARG25 product and released as subsequent versions.<br />
Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012).<br />
The ARG25 product delivers an estimate of surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artefacts of the imaging environment.<br />
Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time. This process is further simplified when the surface reflectance data conforms to a sensor agnostic nested grid, as envisaged for future versions of the ARG25 product.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in Australian land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The ARG25 collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues><uri><![CDATA[http://eos.ga.gov.au/geonetwork/srv/eng/csw?service=CSW&request=GetCapabilities]]></uri><title>Catalogue Service CSW</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact>
root found

<p>Ability to quantify the scale of the daily desertification of Lake Chad over a 10-year period.</p>

<p>97% accuracy achieved without use of confidence layers to constrain results based on terrain or known surface classes.</p>

<p>Improved accuracy over&nbsp;Google &nbsp;Earth &nbsp;Engine &nbsp;Aqua &nbsp;Monitor.</p>

<p>Significant reduction in processing time over standard approaches.</p>

<p>Case 1, Lake Baringo (Kenya):</p>

<ul>
	<li>3.5 GHz Intel processor (4-core), 64GB RAM, Linux computer.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 1-2 minutes for an annual analysis and ~30 minutes for a full time series (11+ years) analysis.</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 2, Central Rangelands (Colombia):</p>

<ul>
	<li>AWS setup has 36 ?virtual CPU? units, 60 GB memory, 300 GB SSD and 2 TB EBS storage.</li>
	<li>Computation time of 5 to 41 seconds for the annual products and ~6 minutes for a full time series (15 year) analysis</li>
</ul>

<p>Case 3, Lake Chad (Northern Cameroon):</p>

<ul dir="ltr">

</ul>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_access_constraints><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Copernicus Australia Hub Sentinel-3-OCLI</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The observations acquired by the mission will be used to in conjunction with other ocean-observing missions to contribute to the Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS) which aims to create a permanent system of ocean observation:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Ocean colour and land reflectance data</li>
	<li>Sea, land and ice surface temperature</li>
	<li>Active fire and burnt area monitoring</li>
	<li>Sea surface topography data</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Europe?s Copernicus programme, and its constituent Sentinel constellation of satellites specifically, has been identified as a critical source of Earth observations from space data for Australia.</p>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-3 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The National Computational Infrastructure in Canberra is the master repository of the data.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues><uri>http://dap.nci.org.au/thredds/remoteCatalogService?catalog=http://dapds00.nci.org.au/thredds/catalog/fj7/Copernicus/Sentinel-3/catalog.xml</uri><title>National Computational Infrastructure THREDDS catalogue</title><options/></field_catalogues><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type>

<ul>
	<li>Monitoring land cover change for environmental monitoring</li>
	<li>Agricultural applications, such as crop monitoring and management to help food security</li>
	<li>Detailed vegetation and forest monitoring and parameter generation (e.g. leaf area index, chlorophyll concentration, carbon mass estimations)</li>
	<li>Observation of coastal zones (marine environmental monitoring, coastal zone mapping)</li>
	<li>Inland water monitoring</li>
	<li>Glacier monitoring, ice extent mapping, snow cover monitoring</li>
	<li>Flood mapping &amp; management (risk analysis, loss assessment, disaster management during floods)</li>
</ul>

<p>Recognising the importance of these satellites, Geoscience Australia, CSIRO, the Government of New South Wales, Government of Queensland and Government of Western Australia have formed a consortium to make data from Europe's Sentinel satellites easier to access and use for businesses, researchers, governments and the general public in the South-East Asia and South Pacific region.</p>

<p>On 4 November 2015, Australia and the European Union agreed to cooperate and to promote exploitation of data from the Sentinel satellites. A key element of this cooperation is around enhancing data access in the South East Asia-South Pacific region, with Australia agreeing to establish a Data Hub to support data access and exploitation in that region.</p>

<p>Geoscience Australia, representing consortium partners, is responsible for the download, maintenance and distribution to users of Sentinel-1 data at various levels of processing in South-East Asia/South Pacific through the regional data hub of Copernicus Australian Area of Interest. The objective of Water Observations from Space is to analyse GA's historic archive of satellite imagery to derive water observations, to help understand where flooding may have occurred in the past. The collection of many hundred thousand WOFLs that make up WO_2.1.5 are too cumbersome to display easily. WO_STATS_2.1.5 provides the mechanism to present and deliver WO_2.1.5 in an easily digestible form, and provides understanding of water in the landscape.</p>
