Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>248b520f-a67d-45c5-a260-dfc3fbc2cfed</value></uuid><vid><value>202</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>SR_MEDOID_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489986720</value></created><changed><value>1489987746</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489987746</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-8d38b89c3c3c1ad019208023e0742588</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Atmospheric correction accuracy is dependent on the quality of aerosol data available to determine the atmospheric profile at time of image acquisition.</p>

<p>BRDF correction is based on low resolution imagery (MODIS) which is assumed to be relevant to medium resolution imagery such as Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI. BRDF correction is applied to each whole Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI scenes and does not account for changes in land cover. It also excludes effects due to topographic shading and local BRDF. This algorithm is dependent on the availability of relevant MODIS BRDF data.</p>

<p>Topographic shading correction algorithm is designed for medium resolution imagery and assumes that hill slopes are resolved by the sensor system (Li et al., 2012). The algorithm assumes that: a. BRDF effect for inclined surfaces is modelled by the surface slope and does not account for land cover orientation relative to gravity (as occurs for some broad leaf vegetation with vertical leaf orientation).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25 Medoid v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat Archive<br />
GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. To improve access to Australia?s archive of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI data, several collaborative projects have been undertaken in conjunction with industry, government and academic partners. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:<br />
? surface reflectance;<br />
? atmospheric condition;<br />
? interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and<br />
? land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.<br />
It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). The SR product delivers modeled surface reflectance from Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI/ data using physical rather than empirical models. Accordingly, this product will ensure that reflective value differences between imagery acquired at different times by different sensors will be primarily due to on-ground changes in biophysical parameters rather than artifacts of the imaging environment.</p>

<p>Integrated Time Series Data<br />
Once consistent and comparable measures of surface reflectance have been retrieved from EO data, it is possible to quantify changes in Earth surface features through time.<br />
Given the growing time series of EO imagery, this landmark facility will streamline the process of reliably monitoring long-term changes in land and water resources.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The low level (aka raw or Level 0 or RCC) data from which this collection is derived is stored at the NCI (working copy), at GA (authoritative Australian archive) and at the USGS (authoritative global archive). The SR collection can be recreated from the low level data. Interim processing levels (aka Level 1T) are also stored at the NCI.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>0950bfb9-2e3f-4537-bfb4-59f98115ec76</value></uuid><vid><value>199</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Derive normalised surface reflectance for sun angle of 45?</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489982455</value></created><changed><value>1489982504</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489982504</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-8cc8b177b324d7f753750ded662b892d</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>Use interpolated, accumulated values for the six base atmospheric parameters to compute the atmospheric and BRDF correction for each pixel and output the normalised surface reflectance for sun angle of 45?.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose/><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>c06d5f0b-9f33-4bbc-9d1f-9e47bb0172b2</value></uuid><vid><value>198</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Determine values for six base atmospheric parameters across each image scene</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489982293</value></created><changed><value>1489982393</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489982393</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-c6bbd15a7f3a6deb3c5df9816005ceab</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<ol>
	<li>Divide scene into quarters and select the nine unique points which form the corners of these quadrants</li>
	<li>Compute the six parameters across optical spectrum at each of the nine points using a Radiative Transfer Model (Modtran 5) and atmospheric state data</li>
	<li>Accumulate values for the six parameters at each of the nine points to correspond to Landsat bands using Landsat spectral response function</li>
	<li>Interpolate accumulated values for the six parameters across image scene using the bilinear method.</li>
</ol>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose/><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Surface Reflectance NBAR+ 25m Geomedian 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The annual geomedian provides an annual reflectance composite for any area of interest within the area covered by the AGDC. It provides a cloud-free overview of the middle surface reflectance value for each year and can be used in further analyses such as Tasselled Cap, Principal Components Analysis and Normalised Difference Indices.</p>

<p>SR eliminates pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and renders more accurate results from analyses, particularly those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>

GA has acquired Landsat imagery over Australia since 1979, including TM, ETM+ and OLI imagery. While this data has been used extensively for numerous land and coastal mapping studies, its utility for accurate monitoring of environmental resources has been limited by the processing methods that have been traditionally used to correct for inherent geometric and radiometric distortions in EO imagery. These projects have enabled implementation of a more integrated approach to image data correction that incorporates normalising models to account for atmospheric effects, BRDF and topographic shading (Li et al., 2012). The approach has been applied to Landsat TM/ETM+ and OLI imagery to create the SR products. The advanced supercomputing facilities provided by the National Computational Infrastructure (NCI) at the Australian National University (ANU) have been instrumental in handling the considerable data volumes and processing complexities involved with production of this product.</p>

<p>Surface Reflectance Correction Models<br />
Image radiance values recorded by passive EO sensors are a composite of:</p>

<ul>
	<li>surface reflectance;</li>
	<li>atmospheric condition;</li>
	<li>interaction between surface land cover, solar radiation and sensor view angle; and</li>
	<li>land surface orientation relative to the imaging sensor.</li>
</ul>

<p>It has been traditionally assumed that Landsat imagery display negligible variation in sun and sensor view angles, however these can vary significantly both within and between scenes, especially in different seasons and geographic regions (Li et al., 2012). However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>

<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality Count 25m 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

This information can also be used to normalise observation counts of particular phenomena. For example what percentage of time did a pixel meet a particular criteria during a particular year.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The different sensor designs of Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI all have different sensor saturation characteristics. The PQ25 layer enables users to exclude observations from a given band where the pixels are saturated (exceed the dynamic range of the sensor). The per-band saturation information in PQ allows users to exclude pixels where their specific band of interest is saturated.</p>

<p>The PQ 25 layer uses two industry standard cloud/cloud shadow detection algorithms to flag pixels that potentially contain cloud and allows the user to generate masks based on either algorithm or both algorithms.</p>

<p>The PQ25-STATS product is a summary of all of the individual PQ_25 layers.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>58e80888-5de3-43ad-82ff-ebe72542093e</value></uuid><vid><value>187</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI Function</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489963097</value></created><changed><value>1489963256</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489963256</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-1212a6aba34052212fd7605ccb5d97e0</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is calculated as follows:</p>

<p>(NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)</p>

<p>where RED and NIR stand for the spectral reflectance measurements acquired in the red and near-infrared regions, respectively.</p>

<p>NDVI values range between -1 and +1, and have been scaled by 10000 to be stored as integers between -10000 and +10000.</p>

<p>Negative values of NDVI (values between 0 and -1) usually correspond to non vegetation targets such as water. Values close to zero (-0.1 to 0.1) generally correspond to barren areas of rock, sand, or snow. Low, positive values usually represent shrub and grassland (approximately 0.2 to 0.4), while high values are indicative of healthy crops or dense vegetation such as temperate and tropical rainforests (values approaching 1).</p>

<p>First described in Tucker (1979) the NDVI has been widely used as a vegetation index to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earths surface. The study by Carlson and Ripley (1997) is widely cited and describes the relationship between NDVI, fractional vegetation cover and leaf area index.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>Live green plants absorb solar radiation in the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) spectral region, which they use as a source of energy in the process of photosynthesis. Leaf cells have also evolved to reflect, scatter and re-emit solar radiation in the near-infrared spectral region. The pigment in plant leaves, chlorophyll, strongly absorbs visible light (from 0.4 to 0.7 micrometres) for use in photosynthesis. The cell structure of the leaves, on the other hand, strongly reflects near-infrared light (from 0.7 to 1.1 micrometres). Hence, live green plants appear relatively dark in the PAR and relatively bright in the near-infrared.<br />
By contrast, clouds and snow tend to be rather bright in the red (as well as other visible wavelengths) and quite dark in the near-infrared.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>8a080d11-ef5b-4940-a5d9-c3c657fa216c</value></uuid><vid><value>188</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>NDVI_25_2.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489729635</value></created><changed><value>1489963801</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489963801</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>2-c8755fb33409e296feeac08431bc7f4e</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>NDVI 25 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>NDVI is used to characterise the amount of vegetation on the Earth's surface and is used as an input parameter in a range of ecological, hydrological and land surface process models.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>64e5bd0c-a5db-4be8-8083-b24eb274f403</value></uuid><vid><value>174</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>ITEM_25_1.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489714813</value></created><changed><value>1489715182</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489715182</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-d7f10caa3cb01acbbc5d2d26cda29f05</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Intertidal Extents Model 25m v. 1.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The purpose of the ITEM v1.0 product is to assist in understanding the extent and elevation profile of the Australian intertidal zone. Examples of where this knowledge can contribute include environmental monitoring applications for migratory bird species, habitat mapping in coastal regions, hydrodynamic modelling, and geomorphology studies of features in the intertidal zone.</p>

<p>Through attribution of the LOT and HOT values modelled for each cell, the extents model can be used to derive an elevation profile of the observed intertidal zone extent on a cell by cell basis. The method employed can be tailored based on user requirements. For example, by dividing the observed tidal range for a cell (HOT-LOT) into 10% interval values, contours can be assigned to the section of the Intertidal Extents Model contained in that cell. These can then be used as a standalone elevation data source, or interpolated to create a continuous intertidal digital elevation model for the cell.</p>

<p>The ability to create an elevation model relative to MSL enables the data to be integrated as a complimentary data source, linking shallow water bathymetry and terrestrial elevation models.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product analyses GA?s historic archive of satellite imagery to derive a model of the spatial extents of the intertidal zone throughout the tidal cycle. The model can assist in understanding the relative elevation profile of the intertidal zone, delineating exposed areas at differing tidal heights and stages.</p>

<p>The product differs from previous methods used to map the intertidal zone which have been predominately focused on analysing a small number of individual satellite images per location (e.g Ryu et al., 2002; Murray et al., 2012). By utilising a full 28 year time series of observations, the methodology enables us to overcome the requirement for clear, high quality observations acquired concurrent to the time of high and low tide.</p>

<p>The modelling process to derive the product utilises a continental scale tidal model developed by Oregon State University (<a href="http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html">http://volkov.oce.orst.edu/tides/tpxo8_atlas.html</a>), applied to the 221 AGDC cells that cover the Australian coastline (Figure 1).</p>

<p>Each Landsat tile in these coastal cells is attributed with a tidal offset, relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL), corresponding to the time of observation acquisition. Tidal offsets are modelled at a single constant location for each 1 degree by 1 degree cell, determined manually and based on the complexity of the coastline contained with the cell.</p>

<p>The time-series of observations for each AGDC cell is then sorted based on the modelled tidal offset, and split into subsets representing 10% percentile intervals of the observed tidal range (OTR) for that cell.</p>

<p>Due the sun-synchronous nature of the various Landsat sensor observations; it is unlikely that the full physical extents of the tidal range in any cell will be observed. Hence, terminology has been adopted for the product to reflect the highest modelled tide observed in a given cell (HOT) and the lowest modelled tide observed (LOT) (Figure 2). These measures are relative to Mean Sea Level, and have no consistent relationship to Lowest (LAT) and Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT).</p>

<p>Each tile observation is masked for pixel quality based on the AGDC PQA layer to exclude pixels flagged for cloud, band saturation and contiguity. The Normalised Difference Water Index (NDWI) (McFeeters, 1996) is calculated for each tile, and a pixel based median NDWI composite derived for each 10% percentile interval of the cell?s OTR.</p>

<p>The ten NDWI composites derived for each cell are used to estimate the extent of exposed substratum at each 10% interval of the OTR, and combined to create the Relative Extents Model.</p>

<p>The Confidence layer is designed to assess the reliability of the Relative Extent Model. Within each tidal range percentile interval, the pixel-based standard deviation of the NDWI values for all tiles in the interval subset is calculated. The average standard deviation across all tidal range intervals is then calculated and retained as a quality indicator in this product layer.</p>

<p>The Confidence Layer reflects the pixel based consistency of the NDWI values within each subset of observations, based on the tidal range. Higher standard deviation values indicate water classification changes not based on the tidal cycle, and hence lower confidence in the extent model. Possible drivers of these changes include:</p>

<p>1. Inadequacies of the tidal model, due perhaps to complex coastal bathymetry or estuarine structures not captured in the model.</p>

<p>2. Change in the structure and exposure of water/non-water features NOT driven by tidal variation. For example, movement of sand banks in estuaries, construction of man-made features (ports etc.).</p>

<p>3. Terrestrial/Inland water features not influenced by the tidal cycle.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact/><field_coverage_content_type/><field_custodian/><field_data_description/><field_data_ingestion/><field_data_ingestion_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_data_ingestion_time_frame><field_data_sources/><field_data_source_contact/><field_data_transfer/><field_developer_title/><field_distribution_entity/><field_documents/><field_doi/><field_ecat_id/><field_features><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) consists of three datasets derived from the Landsat NBAR data managed in the Australian Geoscience Data Cube (AGDC) for the period 1987 to 2015.</p>

<p>The <strong>Coastal Cells shapefile (ITEM_CoastalCells.shp)</strong> identifies the location and extents of the 221 one degree by one degree AGDC cells used in the product, covering the mainland and Tasmanian coastline of the continent (Figure 1). The shapefile also includes information on the lowest (LOT) and highest (HOT) observed tides for the cell, and hence the observed tidal range (HOT-LOT), based on tidal modelling for the time of acquisition of each of the corresponding Landsat tile observations in the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes: </em></strong></p>

<p>AGDC Cell Identifier</p>

<p>Lowest Observed Tide (LOT) ? The lowest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>Highest Observed Tide (HOT) ? The highest modelled tidal offset based on the acquisition times of all observations in the cell. Relative to Mean Sea Level (MSL) (m) x 1000.</p>

<p>The <strong>Relative Extents Model (ITEM_REL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> utilises the tidal information attributed to each tile observation to indicate the spatial extent of intertidal substratum exposed at each 10% percentile of the observed tidal range for the cell.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster: </em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Always water<br />
1 ? Exposed at lowest 0-10% of the observed tidal range<br />
2 ? Exposed at 10-20% of the observed tidal range<br />
3 ? Exposed at 20-30% of the observed tidal range<br />
4 ? Exposed at 30-40% of the observed tidal range<br />
5 ? Exposed at 40-50% of the observed tidal range<br />
6 ? Exposed at 50-60% of the observed tidal range<br />
7 ? Exposed at 60-70% of the observed tidal range<br />
8 ? Exposed at 70-80% of the observed tidal range<br />
9 - Exposed at highest 80-100% of the observed tidal range (land)<br />
-999 ? No Data</p>

<p>The <strong>Confidence Layer (ITEM_CL_mosaic_1987_2015.tif) </strong> reflects the confidence level of the Relative Extents Model, based on the distribution of classification metrics within each of the 10% intervals of the tidal range. The layer should be used to filter region/pixels in the model where the derived spatial extents may be adversely affected by data and modelling errors.</p>

<p>Note: The confidence layer should be utilised on a cell-by-cell basis. Standard deviation values within the confidence layer for a particular cell are not comparable to other cells within the model.</p>

<p><strong><em>Attributes:</em></strong></p>

<p><strong><em>Single Band Integer Raster:</em></strong></p>

<p>0 ? Model is invalid. Indicates pixels where data quality and/or number of observations have resulted in no available observations in one or more of the percentile interval subsets.</p>

<p>-32767 ? No Data</p>

<p>All other values ? The pixel-based average of the NDWI standard deviations calculated independently for each 10% percentile interval of the observed tidal range (x 1000).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_features><field_feedback_contact/><field_hprm_references/><field_images/><field_ingestion_contact/><field_license/><field_maintenance/><field_maintenance_contact/><field_media_contact/><field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-05-16T01:40:13</end_value></field_metadata_catalogue_time_fr><field_metadata_contact/><field_nci_for_codes/><field_nci_geonetwork_id/><field_nci_product_name/><field_nci_project_code/><field_one_line_summary><value>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM) product is a national dataset of the exposed intertidal zone; the land between the observed highest and lowest tide.</value><format>basic_html</format></field_one_line_summary><field_ordering_entity/><field_overview><value><![CDATA[<p>The Intertidal Extents Model (ITEM v1.0) product is a national scale gridded dataset characterising the spatial extents of the exposed intertidal zone, at intervals of the observed tidal range. The current version utilises all Landsat observations (5, 7, and 8) for Australian coastal regions (excluding off-shore Territories) between 1987 and 2015 (inclusive).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_overview><field_principal_contact/><field_principal_contributors/><field_processes/><field_production_stage/><field_product_life_span><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_product_life_span><field_product_type/><field_publishing_entity/><field_publishing_time_frame><value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-06-15T01:40:13</end_value></field_publishing_time_frame><field_qa_contact/><field_qa_time_frame><value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</value><end_value>2017-03-17T01:40:13</end_value></field_qa_time_frame><field_quality_assurance/><field_resource_type>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>8647b469-3fe1-465b-9dbb-f216c6fcd158</value></uuid><vid><value>159</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>external_product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>e8e2a282-c7f3-4b2d-b28f-9e11dae94c9e</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>MOD13Q1 Enhanced Vegetation Index data</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489547953</value></created><changed><value>1489547967</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489547967</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-4dea3f3e2f291c60bb3054045e32f4d5</value></_rev><path/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>f0f8893f-d31d-4e0c-809a-76e3d432f5b0</value></uuid><vid><value>167</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>DLCD_250_2.1.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1489546860</value></created><changed><value>1489709349</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489709349</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-8d025ebab2f6c118bdb6d77387a0668b</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The <em>in situ</em> data shown in Figure 4 were compared with the DLCDv2 class recorded during the same year as the <em>in situ</em> data were collected . Cells highlighted in green in the table above represent a match between the in situ data and the DLCDv2 class. Cells highlighted in yellow represent land covers were the DLCDv2 class was similar (but not the same) as the <em>in situ</em> data. For example irrigated cropping is ?similar? to rainfed cropping. Cells highlighted in red were a mismatch between the <em>in situ</em> data and the DLCDv2 class, for example irrigated cropping is a ?mismatch? for ?tussock grasses ? open?. For 22,645 in situ data points recorded, 31% were a match with the DLCDv2 class, 53% were similar and 17% were a mismatch. This fuzzy approach to accuracy assessment was used to address the challenges of assessing a land cover classification with the best available <em>in situ</em> data, as distinct from <em>in situ</em> data that was collected with the express purpose of assessing the accuracy of an EO land cover classification (Foody 1996). Classes for which no <em>in situ</em> data were available (sugar cane, extraction sites, built-up surface) are not included in the accuracy assessment.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 classification is discriminating the managed land cover classes (in total) from the unmanaged land cover classes with a high degree of accuracy, however there is confusion between the managed classes. For example many of the areas labelled as rainfed cropping in the <em>in situ</em> data are captured as irrigated cropping in the DLCDv2 classification. Based on the in situ data the DLCDv2 the extent of grasses is being undersestimated (low producers accuracy indicating errors of omission (Table 2) and the extent of shrubs is being overestimated (low users accuracy indicating errors of commision). The producers and users accuracy for trees are both &gt;60% indicating a reasonable accuracy for tree cover. However the accuracy for specific tree cover classes (closed versus open) is lower, therefore caution should be exercised in assessing the extent of a specific canopy cover class.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Nadir- looking observations: Earth observing instruments on satellites typically record the dominant cover type rather than the tallest cover type, as a consequence of their nadir-looking configuration. The tallest stratum is used in the ISO classification and the vegetation classification schemes used to capture the <em>in-situ</em> data. As a result, changes in the dominant cover type (for example grasses in savannah ecosystems) may have a larger influence on the EVI signal than changes in taller strata (such as trees in a savannah ecosystem). This means that the DLCDv2 is likely to represent the ?Dominant cover type per epoch? rather than the ?Tallest cover type per epoch?.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Land cover classes that are poorly characterised by EVI: Land cover classes that are difficult to characterise using EVI time series include mines, urban areas, irrigated and rainfed sugar cane. These classes are included in the DLCDv2 for the purposes of providing a complete suite of land cover classes, however variation in the extent of these classes is not well captured using EVI and a single spatial extent is applied to all epochs for these classes. As a consequence users who wish to track the change in extent of these classes should refer to alternate data sources. EVI does not discriminate well between inland waters and salt lakes. For detailed information about the spatial extent of surface water please refer to Water Observations from Space at: <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs">http://www.ga.gov.au/scientific-topics/hazards/flood/wofs</a>.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Persistent green pastures: During periods of higher rainfall the pastures-rainfed class can display similar EVI characteristics to trees-open (persistent high EVI). These classes are discriminated using a 500-metre resolution green reflectance product. This means that changes at the interface between rainfed pastures and open forests may not be detected, and that some afforestion activities may not be detected.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Spatial scale limitations: The 250-metre spatial resolution of the data will limit the use of this data set in studies that depend on the identification of small or detailed features within the landscape i.e. narrow strips of riparian vegetation or managed landscapes where the fields/paddocks are smaller than 250 x 250 metres. The two-year time frame for each map in the map series will limit the capacity to detect short-lived changes in land cover such as low-intensity bushfires i.e. the canopy may recover within a two- year period.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Time scale limitations: Whilst the EVI product is available from 2000 onwards, the first map of the DLCDv2 series starts at January 2002. The land cover results for period January 2000 through to December 2001 are impacted by a lack of pre-existing 250-metre scale information about the land cover in the year 2000. As a consequence they are not included in the DLCDv2.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Terrain shadow: Areas that are affected by terrain shadow at the time of image acquisition will show anomolous results in some instances. Areas with deep shadows in winter may occaisonally be misclassified as alpine grasses and sedges. This is a known artefact and will appear scattered along areas corresponding to valley bottoms.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Severe bushfires: Severe bushfires such as those that occurred on Black Saturday 2009 and the Canberra fire storm in 2003 create unusual EVI responses within a 2-year interval. As a result the land cover class in the map interval following the major fire may be inaccurate. Care should be used when interpreting the land cover maps in areas that have been subject to severe fire.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Dynamic Land Cover Dataset 250 2.1.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>The primary purposes of the DLCDv2.1 product are to provide the Australian government with a standardised land cover dataset for understanding and reporting on land cover change, and to assist policy makers to assess how managed landscapes have responded to droughts, floods and shifts in water allocations. An example application is use within the ABS Land Accounts.<br />
The product has many secondary uses. For example climate and weather modellers will be able use DLCDv2 as a model input parameter. Ecologists, decision makers and carbon modellers will be able to use DLCDv2 to assess how vegetation responds to disturbance including severe fires, floods, cyclones and land clearing activities. The DLCDv2 can also be used as a contextual layer for products such as the Atlas of Living Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The DLCDv2 is the second DLCD product released by GA. It is based on the MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) product MOD13Q1. For more information see: <a href="https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1">https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/modis_products_table/mod13q1</a></p>

<p>The first version of the DLCD product suite (DLCDv1) was published in 2011 and was based on 250 metre resolution MODIS Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) data acquired between April 2000 and April 2008. The DLCDv1 is described in detail at <a href="http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html">http://www.ga.gov.au/earth-observation/landcover.html</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>4b587cdc-d471-4461-a5c9-630810a57370</value></uuid><vid><value>151</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Fractional Cover Processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488762134</value></created><changed><value>1488762291</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488762291</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-7dda954684f63f804e7f83ff2cc6c05e</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>The Fractional Cover (FC) algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program and is described in described in Scarth et al. (2010). It has been implemented by Geoscience Australia for every observation from Landsat Thematic Mapper (Landsat 5), Enhanced Thematic Mapper (Landsat 7) and Operational Land Imager (Landsat 8) acquired since 1987. It is calculated from surface reflectance (SR-N_25_2.0.0).</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a 25m scale fractional cover representation of the proportions of green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-photosynthetic vegetation, and bare surface cover across the Australian continent. The fractions are retrieved by inverting multiple linear regression estimates and using synthetic endmembers in a constrained non-negative least squares unmixing model. For further information please see the articles below describing the method implemented which are free to read:</p>

<p>Scarth, P, Roder, A and Schmidt, M 2010, 'Tracking grazing pressure and climate interaction - the role of Landsat fractional cover in time series analysis', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference,</p>

<p>Schmidt, M, Denham, R and Scarth, P 2010, 'Fractional ground cover monitoring of pastures and agricultural areas in Queensland', Proceedings of the 15th Australasian Remote Sensing &amp; Photogrammetry Conference</p>

<p>A summary of the algorithm developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Centre is also available from the AusCover website: <a href="http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp">http://www.auscover.org.au/purl/landsat-fractional-cover-jrsrp</a></p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>FC provides a 25m x 25m representation of the proportions of living vegetation, dry and dying vegetation (including deciduous trees during autumn, dying grass, etc.), and bare soils across the Australian continent for any point in time in the Landsat archive since 1987. FC can potentially provide insight into areas of dry/dying vegetation and/or bare soil as well as allowing the mapping of living vegetation extent.</p>

<p>Fractional cover data can be used to identify large scale patterns and trends and inform evidence based decision making and policy on topics including wind and water erosion risk, soil carbon dynamics, land management practices and rangeland condition. This information could enable policy agencies, natural and agricultural land resource managers, and scientists to monitor land conditions over large areas over long time frames.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code><uri>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc</uri><title>http://github.com/geoscienceaustralia/fc </title><options/></field_source_code><field_version_number/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>001df937-295d-48cc-9ab6-abd623eb4840</value></uuid><vid><value>157</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC-STATS_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489546067</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489546067</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>6-fc4a2c6b6fa1b8fb08b46a415b2fa0ba</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations/><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australias satellite reception facility or download. The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture &amp; ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent. FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC-25_STATS provides a consistent summary of fractional cover which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery/><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>ae67a355-6435-40c3-918f-0566e39c041c</value></uuid><vid><value>156</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>FC_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488758675</value></created><changed><value>1489446198</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1489446198</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>5-4ca758b3bc5ac6b56257aefd15cc173e</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Based on the comparison with the field data the FC product has an overall Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 11.8%. The error margins vary for the three different layers: green RMSE: 11.0%, non-green RMSE: 17.4% and bare RMSE: 12.5%.</p>

<p>The effect of soil moisture may impact the accuracy of the FC product, and the similarity between some bare soil endmembers and non-photosynthetic vegetation endmembers can lead to model instability. Pixels that show poor model stability are flagged in the model error band as a value of 2, and can be omitted from further analysis if necessary.</p>

<p>FC products have no water masking applied, so erroneous values for green vegetation over the water may appear. These should be ignored and can be masked out by applying the Water Observations (WO) layer.</p>

<p>Occasionally the sum of the three components is not equal to 100%. Differences are usually small and are not rounded in order to preserve what may be useful seasonal indicators.</p>

<p>Landsat 8 OLI has different relative spectral response curves to the Landsat 5 TM and Landsat 7 ETM+ sensors. As a consequence the absolute values for fractional cover estimated from unadjusted Landsat 8 OLI data using the current algorithm may be inaccurate. The magnitude of this impact is described in more detail in Flood (2014).</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Fractional Cover 25</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Fractional cover provides valuable information for a range of environmental and agricultural applications, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Soil erosion monitoring</li>
	<li>Land surface process modelling</li>
	<li>Land management practices (e.g. crop rotation, stubble management, rangeland management)</li>
	<li>Vegetation studies</li>
	<li>Fuel load estimation</li>
	<li>Ecosystem modelling</li>
</ul>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>Nationally consistent information about fractional cover dynamics is essential to addressing a range of natural resource challenges. These include land management practices, air quality, soil erosion, rangeland condition and soil carbon dynamics.</p>

<p>The fractional cover algorithm was developed by the Joint Remote Sensing Research Program (JRSRP) and is described in Scarth et al. (2010). While originally calibrated in Queensland, a large collaborative effort between The Department of Agriculture - ABARES and State and Territory governments to collect additional calibration data has enabled the calibration to extend to the entire Australian continent.</p>

<p>FC_25 was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, the collaborative framework established by the Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS), and collaborative effort between state and Commonwealth governments.</p>

<p>The long term acquisition plan supported by the Landsat program, in combination with Geoscience Australia?s longstanding investment in the on-ground infrastructure required to capture Landsat imagery has made this product possible. Geoscience Australia?s partnership with the National Computing Infrastructure facilities in conjunction with the development of the Australian Geoscience Data Cube - a high performance data framework - makes it possible to analyse the continental archive of fractional cover data.</p>

<p>FC_25 provides a consistent classification which will be an important foundation for land cover mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for natural resource managers, land surface process modellers, carbon modellers, rangeland managers, ecosystem scientists and policy makers.</p>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>da96c73f-1e86-40d8-8689-5583465c7708</value></uuid><vid><value>144</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>2189f0b5-fd8e-47c4-9fe4-3bfd672776e2</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Identify cloud-free ALOS PRISM passes</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488754716</value></created><changed><value>1488754737</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488754737</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-27c098210ff54567b75db0b69fcce22c</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_process_description/>
Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>67daa768-b40f-4ee7-86af-767f569fe949</value></uuid><vid><value>143</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>software_process</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>8d10cf91-8a01-4743-8889-1dfd3d5105f6</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>Full pass/strip processing</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488754542</value></created><changed><value>1488754595</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488754595</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected><value>1</value></revision_translation_affected><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state/><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>1-5b841210a005d23f37b12e3e7737fa81</value></_rev><path/><field_input/><field_output/><field_software_process_desc><value><![CDATA[<p>(See technical report and reference papers http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA20164.pdf)</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_process_desc><field_software_purpose><value><![CDATA[<p>?Full pass? or 'strip' processing rectifies a sequential strip of images taken during a single segment of a satellite?s orbit. the metadata for each separate scene are merged to produce a single, continuous set of orbit and attitude parameters, such that the entire strip of tens of images can be treated as a single image, even though the separate scenes are not actually merged. The merging of orbit data results in a considerable reduction in both the number of unknown orientation parameters and the number of control points required in the sensor orientation adjustment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_software_purpose><field_source_code/><field_version_number/>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>56a576f7-38eb-4622-abfb-c5378d3788f6</value></uuid><vid><value>148</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>AGRI_2.5_0.0.0</value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488517982</value></created><changed><value>1488757785</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488757785</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>3-daaba2428c3e3b999b26b7d0b599ab0a</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>Absolute geometric accuracy: 5.6m CEP90.</p>

<p>Cloudy over some areas.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments/><field_alternate_title><value>Australian Geographic Reference Image 2.5m</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>Reference image ? image to image rectification, image chip source, quality control layer<br />
Basemap ? feature revision and verification, reference layer</p>

<p>Sectors:<br />
Government ? Commonwealth, State and Local<br />
Research institutions<br />
Spatial Information Industry<br />
International satellite operators</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>The Australian Geographic Reference Image (AGRI) is a consistent and accurate reference image for rectification of imagery from multiple sources at resolutions of 2.5 metres or less. The AGRI is needed because the emerging new satellites and other sources of imagery will generate increasing amounts of data. The AGRI can ensure that images from these sources are consistently and accurately registered to allow the maximum extraction of information.</p>

<p>During compilation more than 9560 satellite scenes, totalling over 6 terabytes, were used to produce eight mosaics, covering each of Australia's Universal Transverse Mercator map zones. These mosaics were then combined to produce a single mosaic covering the Australian continent. Intensity and contrast balancing were used to ensure visual consistency across the mosaic while maintaining the dynamic range of the image.</p>

<p>The AGRI was made possible by new scientific and technical capabilities, international collaboration, the Australian spatial information industry, and the leadership and capabilities of Geoscience Australia. Japan's Advanced Land Observing Satellite (ALOS) made possible the complete coverage of high quality imagery, which forms the foundation of the AGRI, as well as accurate data on the satellite orbit. Geoscience Australia was an international collaborator on the ALOS; handling data for the Oceania region. The Barista software, developed by the Cooperative Research Centre for Spatial Information, made the project feasible in terms of time, logistics, and cost. Barista reduced the image registration problem from correction of almost 10 000 scenes to correction of just 105 orbit segments (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The expertise and capability of the Australian spatial information industry was used in the design of GIS databases to manage the survey data and to conduct the many field surveys to remote areas of Australia. The expertise and capabilities of Geoscience Australia staff in both Earth observation and geodesy were also essential inputs to the project (Lewis et al, 2011).</p>

<p>The AGRI provides a consistent base image which will be an important foundation for future mapping and monitoring across Australia. It is a resource for both users and providers of satellite imagery covering Australia in government agencies, research institutions and academia, the spatial information industry, and international satellite operators. The AGRI mosaic and associated datasets are available to the public under the Creative Commons-Attribution licensing terms at cost of transfer from Geoscience Australia.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>The data set is replicated at GA.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>

Attempting to open root on: <uuid><value>29c46cb7-b7ae-4c9d-b6ec-f63df56e268e</value></uuid><vid><value>139</value></vid><langcode><value>en</value></langcode><type><target_id>product</target_id><target_type>node_type</target_type><target_uuid>9b63d36e-b747-4565-9991-99c5a3e112ff</target_uuid></type><status><value>1</value></status><title><value>PQ_25_2.0.0 </value></title><uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></uid><created><value>1488434202</value></created><changed><value>1488517789</value></changed><promote><value>0</value></promote><sticky><value>0</value></sticky><revision_timestamp><value>1488517789</value></revision_timestamp><revision_uid><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>user</target_type><target_uuid>2c1b7b76-12fb-4273-9255-773773f2ddb6</target_uuid><url>/user/1</url></revision_uid><revision_log/><revision_translation_affected/><default_langcode><value>1</value></default_langcode><moderation_state><value>draft</value></moderation_state><workspace><target_id>1</target_id><target_type>workspace</target_type><target_uuid>79bd7389-c9e5-40f5-ace7-5c0ecc466e6c</target_uuid></workspace><_deleted><value>0</value></_deleted><_rev><value>4-358bf8ab14b5581b997bd81c71b7a7e0</value></_rev><path/><field_access_constraints/><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The accuracy of the algorithms for test locations is described in their respective journal articles. However the combination of complex cloud environments, thin cirrus and the scan line corrector error all contribute to the limitations of the PQ25 product . Currently, both the cloud and cloud shadow algorithms rely on the thermal data in order to effectively screen out cloud/cloud shadow affected pixels. The absence of thermal data prevents these algorithms from running, thereby producing a PQ25 product lacking any cloud or cloud shadow masks. This severely can impact any subsequent analysis.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_accuracy_and_limitations><value><![CDATA[<p>The Land Sea Mask, whilst derived from a 100K vector file, the boundary shape may not accurately represent the coastal features visible in the imagery. In order to decrease the chances of eliminating pixels identified as land, the source vector file was buffered (extended) by 150m outwards towards the sea.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_accuracy_and_limitations><field_acknowledgments><value><![CDATA[<p>Landsat data is provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) through direct reception of the data at Geoscience Australia's satellite reception facility or download.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_acknowledgments><field_alternate_title><value>Pixel Quality 25 v. 2.0.0</value><format>basic_html</format></field_alternate_title><field_applications><value><![CDATA[<p>By removing the need for cloud screening and specific scene selection the PQ25 will significantly reduce pre-processing requirements for a wide range of land and coastal monitoring applications and render more accurate results from these analyses, particularly for those utilising time series data. Such applications include various forms of change detection, including monitoring of urban growth, coastal habitats, mining activities, and agricultural production, as well as compliance surveys, scientific research and emergency management.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_applications><field_background><value><![CDATA[<p>As Landsat Imagery becomes more readily available, there has been a rapid increase in the amount of analyses undertaken by researchers around the globe. Most researchers use some form of quality masking schema in order to remove undesirable pixels from analysis, whether that be cloud, cloud shadow, observations over the ocean, or saturated pixels. In the past, researchers would reject partly cloud-affected scenes in favour of cloud-free scenes. However, Landsat time series analysis using all cloud-free pixels has become a valuable technique and has increased the demand for automation of cloud, cloud shadow and saturation detection. Emergency response applications such as flood mapping typically have to contend with individual cloud affected scenes and therefore rely on effective cloud and cloud shadow removal techniques.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product combines established algorithms that detect clouds including the Automated Cloud Cover Assessment (ACCA) (Irish et al. 2006) and Function of mask (Fmask) (Zhu and Woodcock 2012) . ACCA is already widely used within the remote sensing community; it is fast and relatively accurate. Fmask on the other hand is newer, but is rapidly becoming more established, and can provide a more accurate cloud mask than ACCA in certain cloud environments.</p>

<p>The sensor saturation flagging protocols developed for the Web Enabled Landsat Data (WELD) product as described in Roy et al. (2011) are used to flag sensor saturation.</p>

<p>The PQ25 product has similarities to the QAB layer packaged with OLI data, however it uses additional algorithms to detect cloud and cloud shadow, and is available for Landsat?s 5, 7 and 8.</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_background><field_backup_and_recovery><value><![CDATA[<p>None</p>
]]></value><format>basic_html</format></field_backup_and_recovery><field_catalogues/><field_contact>
